British veterans, including Robert Clark, a 96-year-old former prisoner of war, are fighting to stay in their homes due to a lack of funding from local authorities. The council has refused to increase its budget to cover the costs of providing a live-in carer for Clark, citing financial constraints. Clark has received an emergency grant from Help for Heroes to continue paying for his care, but is now facing eviction from his home unless alternative arrangements are made. The council claims that meeting Clark's needs requires a care home fee of £451 per week, which would leave him without sufficient funds to meet his basic needs.

FC Chernomorets Odessa, a Ukrainian Premier League team, is facing severe financial difficulties due to a lack of funding and sponsorship, which has led to the sale of some of its top players to cover salaries. To address this issue, the club is offering luxury houses near the sea to players as part of an effort to cover their outstanding debts. The offer includes homes valued at £67,000, which will help players pay off their debts and potentially avoid relegation and UEFA disqualification. Despite their struggles, the team is determined to improve its performance and climb up the table, traveling to Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk next week to take on Karpaty.

Kestutis Martuzevicius, a 52-year-old Lithuanian gangster, was accused of two murders in his home country and spent nearly five years in a British prison system before being deported back to Lithuania due to a series of delays and breaches of human rights. He claimed depression and mental illness, but was repeatedly denied extradition and instead faced a lengthy and costly process of appealing to the European Court of Human Rights. The court ultimately ruled against Martuzevicius's claims, stating that his detention was lawful and that he did not have a right to challenge it through the European Convention on Human Rights. As a result, Martuzevicius was released from prison and deported back to Lithuania, where he remains free.

A vigilante group of paedophile hunters, posing as children, have been accused of beating up men who agreed to meet them online. The group, known as NWI Nonce Busters, allegedly filmed their attacks and demanded money to keep the footage secret. One teenager was beaten up in Atherton, while another was attacked in Market Place in Wigan. The victims have been charged with grooming and attempted rape, and the perpetrators have been arrested and released on bail. The police are urging anyone with information to come forward and contact the authorities.

Real Madrid's starting lineup returns to training after a week-long break, with key players like Isco, Pepe, and Sami Khedira participating in a session at the Valdebebas complex. The team also includes Isco, who kept the ball from Fabio Coentrao during the first leg against Atletico. Real Madrid faces Malaga in La Liga on Saturday, while they host Barcelona in the Champions League next week. Carlo Ancelotti praised his team's performance in the first half of the match against Atletico, saying they "played really well" despite losing. Defender Dani Carvjal denied attempting to bite Atletico striker Mario Mandzukic during the match.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old man from Stoke-on-Trent, was diagnosed with bowel cancer in July 2012 and underwent chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery to remove his large bowel. Despite receiving a prognosis of 18 months to five years to live, he decided to try cannabis oil as a last resort, which helped him recover and put him on track for a miraculous cure. With the support of his fiancée, Heather, he continued to take cannabis oil until he received a clean bill of health in January 2014, allowing him to tie the knot with her. Today, he is celebrating his five-year anniversary of being cancer-free.

President Barack Obama held a walkabout tour of the Florida Everglades today, holding up the shrinking Everglades as proof that climate change is real and threatening America's national treasures and economies. He emphasized the need for immediate action to combat climate change, citing its impact on the Everglades and surrounding towns, which rely heavily on tourist dollars. Obama's visit aimed to raise awareness about the importance of taking care of the environment and ensuring the long-term sustainability of natural resources. The president's efforts were met with applause from the crowd, highlighting the urgent need for collective action to address climate change.

Javier Hernandez returned to training with Real Madrid after a frustrating season, despite struggling to find consistent playing time. His impressive form in recent weeks has led to speculation about his potential transfer to Manchester United, who have agreed a deal worth around £15 million. However, this deal may be nullified if other clubs bid for him. United have already expressed interest in signing Hernandez, with reports suggesting they value him at around £10 million. This means that any attempt by United to sign him would need to come through other channels.

Bonnie Doll, a 28-year-old Australian gamer, rose to fame playing Call of Duty and has built a massive following on Twitch, with over 45,000 global followers and nearly one million views on her channel. Born in Sweden, Bonnie moved to Australia in 2007 and began streaming on Twitch, initially partnering with the platform to monetize her skills. She has leveraged her gaming expertise to build a lucrative career, earning significant amounts of money from subscriptions, donations, and ad revenue. With a strong social media presence, Bonnie has attracted thousands of devoted fans who tune in to watch her play and engage with her content. Despite facing online harassment, Bonnie remains focused on building a positive community and enjoying her newfound freedom to work from home.

YouTube is set to introduce a paid, subscription-based service for the first time, allowing creators to earn extra revenue from their content. This move comes after several experiments with paid plans, including a 79p/month service launched in May last year. The new service, dubbed YouTube Music Key, will allow users to watch videos offline and without ads, while still earning revenue from their content. The service is expected to be rolled out gradually, starting with select countries and platforms, with prices ranging from £7.99 to £9.99 per month.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rapper and music mogul, has been hospitalized after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges related to a fatal hit-and-run incident involving two men in January. Knight, 49, was involved in a confrontation with Cle "Bone" Sloan, who claimed he attacked him but later recanted his story, and was seriously injured in the process. Knight faces up to life in prison if convicted, despite having prior felony convictions for armed robbery and assault with a gun. His court hearings have been dramatic, with multiple medical conditions and previous run-ins with the law contributing to his struggles. Knight's lawyer claims he was ambushed and tried to escape the altercation, while prosecutors argue he intentionally hit the men.

A nurse at a hospital in Denton, Texas, surprised her paralyzed patient, Bailey Murrill, by getting up from her wheelchair and walking towards her after 11 days of being unable to move due to an inexplicable condition. The nurse was visibly shocked and then burst into tears as Bailey regained feeling and movement in her legs. The incident was captured on camera and shared on social media, garnering over 1 million views. Bailey's mother, Becky Murrill, expressed gratitude for the nurse's kindness and support during her recovery.

Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London after a previous attempt was rebuffed due to concerns about the quality of the interview. The Swedish authorities had sought to question Assange about alleged sex crimes committed in 2010, but he has denied these claims. A statute of limitations for prosecution may apply in Sweden, which could delay the process. Assange has expressed concerns that speaking with prosecutors in person would compromise his safety and potentially lead to extradition to the US, where he faces severe penalties.

Pete Bennett, a former winner of the UK version of Big Brother, has spoken publicly about his struggles with homelessness and addiction. He was a popular contestant on the show in 2006 and released a bestselling autobiography, but struggled with fame and wealth, leading to a downward spiral of substance abuse and personal issues. In recent years, he has sought treatment and attempted to rebuild his life, including pursuing acting roles. However, he has relapsed and is currently living off the charity of friends, struggling to find stable employment.

Borussia Dortmund secured a comfortable 4-2 win over Paderborn at Signal Iduna Park, moving into third place in the Bundesliga table. Manager Jurgen Klopp announced his departure at the end of the season, leaving the team with a realistic chance of qualifying for European competition. The win kept Dortmund ahead of relegation-threatened Paderborn, who had been struggling to avoid the drop. The match saw a two-goal cushion for Dortmund, courtesy of goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Shinji Kagawa, while defender Durm and midfielder Ginter also scored. The win keeps Dortmund in contention for a top-six finish, with manager André Breitenreiter's team now just three points behind sixth-placed Augsburg.

Lee Min-bok, a South Korean defector, is launching hundreds of Hollywood comedy films into North Korea despite warnings from authorities about their potential harm. Despite initial laughter during the film, he admits he would never watch the movie again due to its portrayal of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Lee is part of a group sending thousands of copies of the film across the border, despite the risk of retaliation from North Korea. The move is seen as an attempt to expose the regime's propaganda efforts and bring attention to the human cost of their actions.

An Israeli-developed thermal protection case called Optimal has been created to prevent overheating issues caused by sending dozens of messages or playing games on a phone. The case features micro-fans to cool the device down and resistance coils to warm it up if necessary. It monitors the phone's temperature and alerts the user if it gets too hot, and can even engage anti-freeze protection to prevent damage. The case is designed to work with various smartphones, including Apple, Samsung, Nexus, HTC, and Xperia devices, and is expected to launch on April 9th through an Indiegogo campaign.

A Russian fishing vessel, the Dalniy Vostok, carrying 132 people, sank off the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia, resulting in at least 54 deaths and 15 missing. Over 60 people were rescued from the water, mostly from Myanmar, Ukraine, Lithuania, and Vanuatu. The ship went down in the Sea of Okhotsk within 15 minutes of encountering difficulties, with the most likely cause being a collision with an obstacle. An investigation is underway, but it is believed that the vessel may have keeled over due to excessive weight on its deck.

The article reviews ten food-related apps available for download, highlighting their features and usefulness. These apps cover various aspects of food, such as meal planning, budgeting, and discovering new restaurants, and are designed to make planning and managing meals easier. Many of these apps seem to be obvious choices for anyone interested in food, but some stand out due to their unique features and functionalities. Overall, the apps provide a convenient way to access a wide range of information and tools to enhance one's relationship with food.

Jeremy Clarkson, 53, has taken a break from his Top Gear duties to spend a family holiday in Barbados with his estranged wife Frances, 53, who has been enjoying a relaxing getaway in the Caribbean. The couple has been separated for years, and Clarkson has continued to battle his personal issues despite being sacked from the show. During his Easter break, Frances showcased her toned physique in a white bikini, revealing her tanned figure to a crowd. The couple has two children together, and Clarkson has been trying to revive his career since his departure from Top Gear.

Aldi, a discount supermarket chain, is facing criticism from regulatory bodies for failing to clearly disclose a 0.5% surcharge on credit card fees for transactions made using their tap and go contactless payment system. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) investigated Aldi after discovering the surcharge was not properly disclosed, and found that the supermarket had not provided clear warnings to customers about the fee. The company claims it had taken steps to address the issue, including placing signs at stores and informing cashiers, but critics argue that these measures are insufficient. The incident has sparked calls for greater transparency around credit card fees and the use of contactless payment systems.

A wartime blunder occurred on the HMS Ulster Queen, a battle cruiser converted from a ferry carrying millions of pounds of Russian bullion bound for America. The blunder involved a secret operation to unload the gold and silver bars onto a waiting boat, but it ended in disaster when one box slipped and fell into the Clyde River. The incident was uncovered by a secret diary kept by the ship's engineer, Leonard H. Thomas, which revealed the extent of the blunder and its consequences. The loss of the bullion resulted in significant financial losses for the US government, while also highlighting the risks faced by Allied forces during wartime.

Luis Suarez admitted to biting an Italian defender during the World Cup, but claimed he didn't do so. His wife Sofia revealed that he initially denied the incident, but eventually confessed after seeing footage on TV. Suarez joined Barcelona from Liverpool in July and has been playing well for the team. Despite facing a four-month ban, Suarez remains a key player for the Spanish giants.

A 48-year-old man, Ranulfo Perez, was arrested for allegedly groping a 16-year-old girl in Times Square while dressed as the Cookie Monster. The incident occurred when the girl was shown around a Toys R Us store with her tour group, and Perez allegedly touched her breasts without consent. Perez was released after the authorities couldn't determine if it was him or another character. The incident is part of a growing trend of costumed characters in Times Square, which has led to increased calls for regulation and licensing fees. Perez was charged with forcible touching and harassment, and was released due to lack of evidence.

A 15-year-old son, Marc Wabafiyebazu, and his 17-year-old brother, Jean, were involved in a fatal gunfight with a group of Miami drug dealers after attempting to rob them at a home in the Coral Way area. The incident occurred on Monday, and both brothers were arrested and charged with felony murder and attempted robbery. Marc was taken into custody, while his brother was shot and killed. His mother, Roxanne Dubé, was appointed as the Canadian Consul General in Miami in November, but she arrived in the city in February.

A 42-year-old Iraqi doctor, Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, was found guilty of voyeurism after secretly filming men in the showers at a gym in Newham, East London. He cut holes in Lynx shampoo bottles to conceal iPhones and cameras, allowing him to film men using the showers. Al-Atraqchi worked at Custom House Surgery in North London and faced being struck off the medical register due to his actions. He pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined £500 and ordered to pay costs.

A former US Army enlistee, John T. Booker Jr., was arrested and charged with attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base in Kansas. Booker, who enlisted in 2014, had planned to use explosives to harm American soldiers, particularly those stationed at the base, which is home to the 1st Infantry Division. Two confidential informants helped him build the bomb, which was inert and would not have exploded. Booker was arrested after being stopped near the base while making final preparations for the attack, and another man, Alexander E. Blair, was also charged with failing to report a felony related to the incident.

A new study found that children who experience stressful events such as a death or illness in the family, divorce or separation, are three times more likely to develop type 1 diabetes. Researchers analyzed data from over 10,000 families with children aged 2-14 and found that these children were more likely to be diagnosed with the condition. The study suggests that damaging events in childhood can affect the development of beta cells in the pancreas, leading to an increased demand for insulin production. This highlights the importance of considering the impact of stressful events on children's health, particularly in relation to genetic predisposition.

A 15-year-old African American teenager, Jamar Nicholson, and his friend Jason Huerta were shot by a police officer in South Los Angeles after the officer believed a toy gun was real. The incident occurred on February 10, and both men are suing the city of Los Angeles for $20 million, claiming they were mistaken about the situation. They argue that the officer's actions were discriminatory and that they pose no threat to police officers or themselves. The lawsuit claims that the officer's use of force was unjustified and that the LAPD should return to its former impartiality. The case highlights concerns over racial profiling and police brutality in the US.

A man was found sleeping on a baggage claim conveyor belt at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, causing concern among passengers who were more interested in finding their luggage than the man's slumber. The incident occurred during a time when jet lag and excessive drinking might have contributed to the individual's decision to take a nap. Other passengers were seen laughing and taking photos of the situation, but officials took steps to prevent similar incidents in the future by releasing images of the man being scanned through an X-ray machine. The man was later released unharmed, and no further action was taken against him.

Cadbury is releasing a limited-edition super bar with seven different fillings, including Dairy Milk Caramel, Fruit & Nut, Whole Nut, Oreo, Daim, and Turkish. This marks the company's first attempt at creating a bar with multiple fillings since 1921. The unique offering was developed through a collaboration between Cadbury and food artist Prudence Staite, who conducted research showing that consumers prefer trying new flavors recommended by others. The seven-flavor bar is available exclusively online and in select stores, rather than being sold in supermarkets.

A 72-year-old former Nigerian general, Muhammadu Buhari, has won the presidential election, marking a significant shift towards greater political maturity in West Africa. Despite being criticized for past corruption and authoritarian tendencies, Buhari's campaign focused on addressing corruption and tackling Boko Haram, a militant Islamist group that has plagued the country. His victory comes after a peaceful transfer of power from President Goodluck Jonathan, who was accused of running a corrupt administration. Buhari's campaign emphasized the need for economic development and improved governance, resonating with a population tired of years of misrule and corruption.

Daniel O'Reilly, formerly known as Dapper Laughs, has traveled from Doha to Sydney, Australia, and back again, documenting his journey on social media. He has been involved in controversy due to his past comments, including making jokes about rape and using derogatory language towards women. Despite facing backlash, he has continued to post videos and engage with fans, including interacting with female air stewards and sharing humorous moments. His latest video features him joking about meeting two female air stewardesses and asking them out, sparking criticism from comedians and critics alike.

A British Muslim family, consisting of nine individuals, including the 21-year-old son Waheed Ahmed, who was arrested in Turkey along with several others, are returning to England due to their involvement with ISIS. They were caught crossing into Syria and are expected to face terror charges. The family, who are originally from Kashmir, have been living in Rochdale, England, since 2006. The government's decision to allow them to return to the UK despite their alleged ties to extremist groups raises concerns about the effectiveness of the country's counter-terrorism strategy.

Avril Lavigne, 30, has revealed she has Lyme disease, a bacterial infection caused by a tick bite, which left her bedridden for five months. The illness, which can cause debilitating symptoms such as extreme fatigue, joint pain, and memory loss, was initially misdiagnosed as a flu or exhaustion. Her symptoms persisted despite medical treatment, prompting her to seek help from specialists, who eventually confirmed the diagnosis. Now recovering, Avril credits her loved ones, including her husband Chad Kroeger, for their support during her long recovery.

In August 2013, a mob in the Egyptian village of Kafr Hakim torched a Christian church, leading to widespread attacks on other churches and businesses in the region. A total of 71 people were sentenced to life in prison for their roles in the incident, with 52 of them receiving sentences in absentia. The victims include several members of the Coptic community, who were targeted due to their faith. The attacks were linked to the rise of the Muslim Brotherhood, which had backed then-President Mohamed Morsi during his presidency.

Two individuals, aged 18 and 19, have been charged with attempting to carry out an ISIS-inspired terror plot in Australia. The arrests came after five young men were arrested in a major counterterrorism operation in Melbourne. The two suspects, identified as Sevdet Besim and another unnamed individual, were charged with conspiring to commit terrorist acts. Authorities described the plot as being linked to a major national commemoration event, Anzac Day, where there was a risk to the public.

Aston Villa's Tim Sherwood ridiculed Carles N'Zogbia's outrageous outfit during training, with the goalkeeper taking to Twitter to describe it as "the worst ever". N'Zogbia has been a regular fixture under Sherwood since his appointment in February, featuring in several games. The Irish international wore a flamboyant shirt and trousers combination during training, which didn't sit well with Sherwood. This latest display may have sparked some choice words from the former Tottenham manager. Villa currently sit six points clear of the Premier League relegation zone.

A British photographer, Laura Stevens, created a therapeutic photography project "Another November" capturing the stages of grief following a breakup through posed photographs of women. The series, inspired by her own painful break-up, aims to convey the emotional journey of loss and self-discovery. Through intimate and often eroticized images, the photographer explores the complexities of female experiences, including loneliness, appetite, and identity reconstruction. The project has been exhibited in various galleries and publications, including The National Portrait Gallery and The Washington Post.

Andy Murray, the British tennis player, showed nerves on his wedding rehearsal on Friday, but managed to compose himself when visiting the cathedral to run through the service with his fiancée Kim Sears. The couple has been together for 10 years and got engaged last year after a brief split in 2010. On Saturday, they will marry in their hometown of Dunblane, Scotland, surrounded by friends and family. A ceremony will follow, followed by a reception.

A female Pennsylvania police officer, Officer Lisa Mearkle, is facing criminal homicide charges after fatally shooting an unarmed motorist, David Kassick, in a confrontation in which footage of the incident was recorded using a stun gun. Mearkle claims she shot Kassick in self-defense, but prosecutors argue that the video shows otherwise. The prosecution plans to present the footage in court, which allegedly shows Kassick laying face-down on the ground with his back towards Mearkle. Mearkle is currently free on bail and suspended without pay, and her defense team has requested that the video be kept out of the courtroom. The case is set to go to trial, with a preliminary hearing already held.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 World Champion Michael Schumacher, returned to the racing circuit after a week-long absence due to an 100mph crash at the Oschersleben circuit in Germany. He made his pre-season test debut in Formula 4, where he was spotted accidentally driving through gravel while testing his car. This marks the first time he has been involved in a high-speed incident since the crash. Schumacher is seeking to follow in his father's footsteps in the sport.

A forthcoming eight-episode docu-series on E! will follow Bruce Jenner's journey as he transitions into a woman, following a 20/20 special featuring his 20-year-old daughter Kim Kardashian. The series aims to educate and create empathy through Bruce's personal story, despite concerns from his sons Burt, Brandon, and Brody that he may reveal too much. The show will feature never-before-seen footage from the 20/20 interview, where Bruce discussed his struggles with his identity and his desire to live openly as a woman. The series is set to premiere on July 27 and will be produced by E! and the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation (GLAAD), with Bruce signing a contract to participate.

The RSPCA is considering dropping its "pointless" pursuit of fox hunting prosecutions after the collapse of its latest case against William Bryer, a joint master of the Cattistock Hunt in Dorset. The charity had previously spent £22.5 million pursuing prosecutions under the Hunting Act, but has no remaining legal actions left. Critics argue that many hunters are prosecuted under the law for poaching, rather than fox hunting, and that the charity should focus on rescuing and rehabilitating animals rather than pursuing prosecutions. The RSPCA is reviewing its policy on hunting cases, citing concerns about the effectiveness of the Hunting Act and the need to prioritize animal welfare.

A former police officer, Darren Stanton, claims that liars often stare, contrary to the traditional notion that they cannot meet eye contact. According to Stanton, people who are fibbing will exhibit certain physical cues such as twitching, blinking, and micro-expressions, which can indicate deception. Stanton, who is now a body expert, uses these techniques to detect lies and has gained recognition as the UK's top human lie detector. His methods involve studying psychology, neuroscience, and behavioral patterns to identify dishonesty. Stanton appears on TV shows, including ITV's This Morning, where he shares his expertise with hosts Philip Schofield and Amanda Holden.

The article discusses the significance of Holy Week, also known as Easter, in the Christian calendar, highlighting its unique aspects and its connection to the human condition. Easter is a time when Christians reflect on the true meaning of faith and the cycle of the Christian year, while also acknowledging the commercialization and cultural tensions surrounding Christmas. Despite this, the article argues that Easter remains a powerful symbol of hope and transformation, representing the possibility of renewal and rebirth. The three-day Triduum - Good Friday, Holy Saturday, and Easter Sunday - marks the culmination of the Easter season, offering a chance to confront the darkness and uncertainty of life and ultimately emerge transformed.

A new app called Camoji has been released that allows users to create and send animated GIFs on Facebook Messenger, making it easier to share fun and creative content. The app uses Instagram-style filters and effects, and users can record and share GIFs with others in real-time. This is the first time Facebook has allowed third-party apps to integrate with Messenger, giving users more options for expressing themselves. With over 600 million monthly active users, Camoji is just one of many new apps set to be added to the Messenger platform.

Labour leader Ed Miliband addressed the issue of immigration in his speech, emphasizing the importance of speaking English as a shared language for communities to thrive. He acknowledged that his party had previously been "too timid" on this issue, but vowed to take action to crack down on exploitation of migrant workers. A new task force will be established to tackle abuse and prosecution of employers, while also promoting education and training for migrant workers to improve their language skills. Miliband also called for greater investment in public services, such as the NHS, which relies heavily on migrant contributions.

Four terrified puppies were rescued after being strapped in a cage to the roof of a van on the freeway in Ohio. The incident occurred during a 300-mile journey from Nova, Ohio to Pennsylvania, where the parents, Wendell and his wife, were stopped by police due to concerns about animal welfare. The puppies, a mix of breeds, were found to be wind-battered and huddled together in the cage, but had no injuries. The parents claimed they were transporting the dogs to their sister's family in Pennsylvania due to their father's inability to care for them. The incident sparked outrage, leading to a Facebook group calling for the puppies to be adopted.

British gymnast Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since the 2012 Olympics after being named in the squad for the European Championships. He previously won silver and bronze medals in pommel horse and team events at the London Games. Smith joins a talented group of athletes, including world all-around silver medallist Max Whitlock and four-time Commonwealth Games champion Claudia Fragapane. The European Championships will be held in Montpellier from April 15 to 19, featuring individual all-around and apparatus events. Smith is currently dating actress Lucy Mecklenburgh.

Mohammed Dahbi, a New York taxi driver, was ordered to pay $10,000 in damages to a lesbian couple after being accused of discriminating against them by telling them to stop kissing in the back of his cab. The incident occurred on September 18, 2011, when Dahbi allegedly yelled at the couple, calling them "b***", "c***", and "whores" after they refused to pay their fare and walk away. A judge found Dahbi guilty of discrimination and ordered him to pay a $5,000 civil penalty to the city. Dahbi claims he did not mean to discriminate and says the incident was just a misunderstanding, but the court disagrees, stating that his words were discriminatory and unacceptable.

Jonas Gutierrez, an Argentinian midfielder, was dropped from Newcastle United's starting lineup after a fallout with head coach John Carver following a heated exchange on social media. The 31-year-old was named among the substitutes for Sunday's 3-1 defeat at Tottenham, where he was later released by the club due to "selection reasons". This decision comes after a tumultuous period for Gutierrez, who had previously been praised for beating testicular cancer. Despite being named among the substitutes, Gutierrez expressed frustration over the treatment he received from the club, citing a desire to play for Newcastle again. His release marks the end of his seven-year tenure at the club.

Islamic State militants infiltrated the Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus, entering through Jordan's Nasib border crossing, and took control of the camp, threatening the capital's stability. The militants, affiliated with ISIS, used the camp as a base to launch attacks against the Syrian government and its allies. The situation escalated when Jordan closed its border with Syria due to clashes between rebels and government forces, allowing the militants to enter the camp. The UN aid workers have been struggling to deliver food and medical supplies to the camp, which has been under siege for nearly two years. The militants have also killed dozens of people, including a blindfolded and bound couple, in gruesome stonings, according to reports.

Amanda Peake Glover, a devoted mother of four, collapsed while running the Myrtle Beach half marathon on Saturday, sparking shock and grief among those close to her. The 34-year-old mother of four, who was also a co-owner of an Elgin fitness center, had recently completed the half marathon with her brother just a month prior. Her sudden death has left her husband, Benji, and their four children heartbroken. The cause of her passing remains unknown, but it appears to have been related to the physical exertion of running.

Labour's shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, was left stumped when asked to calculate seven times six in front of a packed audience at a speech in Leeds. The question caught him off guard, prompting him to laugh nervously and say "the answer... the answer is 42". He later explained that he relied on his mother-in-law for help with maths due to his reliance on her expertise. This came after he admitted that he hadn't received any maths questions on live TV since revealing that he still uses his mother-in-law for math problems.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott are the sixth English pair to score over 100 runs together, joining Hobbs and Sutcliffe, Cook and Strauss, Cook and Pietersen, Trescothick and Vaughan, and Bell and Pietersen in this remarkable feat. This marks the third time England captain Alastair Cook has achieved this milestone, alongside Jonathan Trott. Their partnership stands as one of the most successful in English cricket history, having reached 10 occasions where both players have scored over 100 runs together. The duo follows in the footsteps of other notable partnerships such as Hobbs and Sutcliffe, Cook and Strauss, and others.

A New York City skin clinic called Skin Laundry offers a popular laser treatment that promises to tighten skin and improve complexion after just ten minutes. The treatment involves a two-step process, where a nurse applies gel and then a pulsed light to the skin, leaving it feeling smooth and glowing. Clients must sign a waiver releasing their personal information to a funeral director and coroner, but claim that the risk of serious side effects is low. Despite concerns about the waiver, the clinic has seen success among its regular customers, with many reporting improvements in their skin.

Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's highly anticipated boxing match has seen rapid ticket sales, with over 10,000 tickets selling out within minutes on Thursday night. The pair's face-off is scheduled for May 1, and tickets went on sale just 24 hours prior to the event. The MGM Resorts Box Office was overwhelmed with calls, while other online platforms like StubHub and Ticketmaster reported similar sell-outs. The pair's weight-in took place earlier today, with tickets selling quickly, and now fans can only hope to secure a spot at the mega-fight in Las Vegas.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio, 34, is recovering from a medical procedure at UCLA Hospital in Los Angeles after undergoing treatment for "constant headaches". She was spotted partying at the Coachella festival in California over the weekend before the incident. Ambrosio had previously revealed she had booked the appointment two weeks prior to the event. The Brazilian supermodel is currently under observation at the hospital, where she will be receiving treatment.

A rowing team from Oxford University was rescued by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) after becoming stranded in the Thames due to strong winds and rising water levels. The team, consisting of women, were training for the Boat Race when they encountered difficulties navigating through choppy waters. The RNLI arrived on the scene and successfully retrieved the team, ensuring their safety. The incident occurred during a busy period for the RNLI, with the organization having saved over 3,600 lives since its inception in 2002. The rescue effort was praised by the RNLI's helmsman, who noted that it was the first time he had assisted a team in this situation.

Lucas Moura has expressed admiration for Lionel Messi, praising his skills as one of the greatest players in the world. He considers Messi to be the best player globally, citing his exceptional technique and vision on the pitch. Moura believes Messi's ability to dominate games makes him nearly unbeatable. The Paris Saint-Germain midfielder has stated that playing against Messi would be "very difficult" due to his exceptional skillset. Despite this, Moura remains optimistic about the upcoming match, saying they will need to work hard to stop him if they hope to win.

Zayn Malik's personal life has been under scrutiny due to his relationship with Little Mix singer Perrie Edwards, which has come under fire after Swedish model Martina Olsson accused him of cheating on her during a holiday in Thailand. The 22-year-old couple was seen jetting off on a romantic getaway, sparking rumors of a possible breakup. This is not the first time Zayn has been accused of cheating, with previous partners including Courtney Webb and Lauren Richardson coming forward with similar allegations. Zayn has denied the claims, stating that he loves Perrie and apologizing for any perceived betrayal.

A recent surge in "religious freedom" bills in Arkansas and Indiana has sparked widespread outrage and criticism from businesses, including Walmart, which has faced backlash for its response to the legislation. The move has created a significant threat to the LGBTQ+ community, particularly young people, who are increasingly demanding greater acceptance and inclusion. The Bible's injunction on unconditional love has been cited as a justification for the backlash, but critics argue that it is being applied selectively, with some businesses choosing not to take a stand despite having a strong track record of supporting diversity and inclusivity. This shift in public opinion suggests that the tide of public opinion is turning against intolerance and discrimination, making it a bad business model for companies like Walmart to ignore.

Jake Hall scored a crucial goal for Boston United, impressing his girlfriend Chloe Lewis in attendance at the match. The TOWIE star's on-screen girlfriend was seen cheering him on from the sidelines. Hall's impressive performance helped the team secure a 2-0 victory over Tamworth. Hall's secret romance with Hollywood actress Lindsay Lohan was reported earlier in the week, but both parties have denied any romantic involvement. The Boston United player expressed his excitement about playing for the club again, stating that he loves the atmosphere and feels welcomed by the fans.

A US military contingent is training Iraqi and Kurdish forces to combat ISIS, with some foreign volunteers joining the effort. The US military believes its support is sufficient, while others argue that external aid is necessary to address the root causes of the conflict. Foreign fighters, including Canadians and Americans, are volunteering to join the fight, with some groups setting up online recruitment drives. The US military is concerned that foreign involvement could exacerbate sectarian divisions and create a false narrative that ISIS is the protector of a persecuted minority.

A British soldier, Sergeant Norman Turgel, met a Polish girl, Gena, in a Nazi concentration camp during World War II. Despite the odds against them, they fell in love despite being separated by the harsh conditions of the camp. After the British liberated the camp, they were reunited and married, starting a life together. However, their happiness was cut short when Gena died of typhus and Norman was left alone, prompting Major Leonard Berney to intervene and help them rekindle their romance.

A 6-hour drive from Kathmandu to the town of Gorkha, Nepal, reveals a stark contrast to the devastation caused by the country's devastating earthquake. The town is surprisingly intact despite being near the epicenter, with only 10 collapsed or severely damaged houses and a hospital that is overcrowded with injured patients. International medical teams, including those from Switzerland and Denmark, are working tirelessly to provide aid and treatment to the injured, while also assisting in evacuating those in need. The Swiss Humanitarian Aid Unit and other organizations are providing critical assistance, including surgical operations and search and rescue efforts.

In Indonesia, President Joko Widodo has maintained a tough stance on drug smugglers since taking office, rejecting attempts to grant clemency to Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, who were convicted of participating in a failed heroin smuggling plot. The pair, along with six others, were arrested in 2014 and sentenced to death after being found guilty of trafficking over 8 kilograms of heroin. The Indonesian court rejected their appeals, casting a further pall over the Bali Nine, a group of Australians who were also involved in the plot. The group, which included Andrew Chan, 31, and Myuran Sukumaran, 33, had been sentenced to life in prison, and their fate remains uncertain after a recent rejection of their clemency requests.

A recent study suggests that the Earth may have collided with a body similar to the planet Mercury, potentially explaining the presence of a hot core and unusual elemental ratios in the planet's mantle. The collision, believed to have occurred around 4.5 billion years ago, would have generated heat necessary for the Earth's core and possibly even created the moon. The study proposes that a Mars-sized body, composed similarly to Mercury, collided with the Earth, producing radioactive elements that fueled the planet's core. This collision could also account for the similarities between the Earth and the moon, as well as the presence of rare earth elements in both.

Red Bull's Formula One team has experienced a tough 18-month period since their dominant four-year reign at the top of the sport ended in 2013. Despite Daniel Ricciardo's efforts, they struggled to regain their footing, finishing last in the championship last season alongside Mercedes. This year, Ricciardo aims to bounce back with improved performance, having worked with a martial artist to fine-tune his stance. With Mercedes currently leading the pack, Ricciardo faces stiff competition from Sebastian Vettel and others, but he hopes to pick up wins and make a strong comeback.

A drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office in protest against the government's nuclear energy plans. The drone, which was four-propeller and 50 centimeters wide, was spotted by a member of the Prime Minister's staff and contained a small amount of radioactive substance. Police and bomb squad were called to investigate, and tests are underway to determine if the drone posed any threat. The incident occurred while Prime Minister Abe was away in Indonesia attending a conference. The government has announced plans to decommission the reactor at a nearby nuclear power plant, despite concerns about its safety.

The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) is a complex and multifaceted terrorist organization that presents itself as a global entity, but its true intentions are rooted in a desire for power and control. Despite being portrayed as a shocking and terrifying force, the group's leadership recognizes that its primary goal is to establish a caliphate in Iraq and Syria, and seeks to exploit the chaos and instability in the region to achieve this objective. The group's use of social media platforms, particularly the internet, has become a significant factor in its recruitment and dissemination of propaganda, making it a powerful tool for spreading its message and attracting new members. As a result, the group continues to pose a significant threat to global security, despite being defeated in several major battles in Iraq.

The UK's leaders, David Cameron and Nick Clegg, sat on the Gogglebox sofa during a televised debate, while Ed Miliband appeared alongside Kate Winslet in a Titanic reference. The Labour leader posed a direct challenge to the Prime Minister, saying "Debate me like one of your French girls", referencing the iconic line from the 1997 film Titanic. The debate featured images of various party leaders, including Nicola Sturgeon, who looked skeptical, and Nigel Farage, who was shown wearing a black ranger costume. The event sparked memes featuring the leaders being superimposed onto characters from popular culture, such as Christopher Steed and Stephen Webb from Gogglebox.

Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster during a 4-2 loss to Manchester United. Eighty-three people died in the 1958 crash, and a similar incident occurred earlier that day. The incident led to a 24-hour ban on all matches until further notice due to concerns over safety. Police praised "the overwhelming majority" of fans for behaving safely, while also taking steps to prevent future incidents. The incident has sparked renewed calls for improved security measures at stadiums.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has hinted that the club may look to sign best youngsters from rival teams to strengthen their first-team squad, as they struggle to find suitable candidates from their own academy. The team currently lacks a strong core of homegrown players, with many of their key players nearing the end of their contracts or looking to move elsewhere. Pellegrini has expressed frustration over the lack of progress in developing young players, citing the need for patience and time to nurture them through the ranks. Despite this, City are willing to take risks to address their shortage, with several promising youngsters being linked with the club.

A 28-year-old Jehovah's Witness woman, Jenny-Lee, refused to accept a blood transfusion during her pregnancy despite being told she could have given birth via a caesarean section and undergone chemotherapy. Her mother, Heather, believes her daughter prioritized her unborn child above all else and died shortly after giving birth to a stillborn baby. The incident has sparked controversy, with some blaming the hospital for not testing for leukemia earlier and others condemning the mother's actions. The mother's refusal to accept blood transfusion led to her death, which was later ruled a preventable cause of death under Australian law.

A Muslim father, Mohammad Liaqat, launched a violent attack on Xavier Bowers, the headteacher of Mount Carmel School in Accrington, Lancashire, after being banned from having a beard due to a school uniform policy. Liaqat, who has a child at the school, stormed into the school and began a racist tirade against the staff, calling them "racist" and "white". He physically assaulted Bowers and other staff members, including going to another school to continue his rant. Liaqat was arrested and charged with assault and racially or religiously aggravated behavior after a three-day trial. He was remanded into custody and will face sentencing in June.

China's government has reported a significant increase in arrests and seizures of illicit substances, with over 133,000 people and 43.3 tons of narcotics seized during a six-month anti-drug campaign. The crackdown resulted in 61 deaths and 657 injuries among police officers, but also saw a 44.9% increase in narcotics seizures compared to the previous year. The government has pledged to continue its efforts to combat drug use, despite reports of online drug trafficking becoming increasingly problematic. Several high-profile celebrities, including Jaycee Chan, son of Jackie Chan, have been arrested and charged for their involvement in drug-related incidents.

A new species of glass frog, Hyalinobatrachium dianae, has been discovered in eastern Costa Rica, characterized by its translucent skin that allows its internal organs to be seen. The frog was found in the mountains of the country and has a distinctive call, unlike other glass frogs. Its translucent skin makes it stand out due to its bright green coloration on its back and white eyes, which resemble those of the popular Muppet character Kermit. The discovery was made by scientist Brian Kubicki, who named the species after his mother, Janet Kubicki.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have returned to Kensington Palace to prepare for the imminent birth of their new baby, following a weekend trip to Kate's family home in Berkshire. The couple, whose second child is due on Saturday, will spend the next six weeks on paternity leave, with William completing his air ambulance pilot training ahead of schedule. The news comes as Kensington Palace reveals that the couple will reunite at the Lindo Wing at St Mary's Hospital in London, where Kate gave birth to their previous son George in 2013. The couple's second child is expected to arrive on Saturday, and the palace says William will take unpaid leave until June 1, during which time he will be unavailable for public engagements.

A 67-year-old man named Maurice Thibaux stormed onto the catwalk during Sydney's Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, claiming the noise from the music was similar to a jumbo jet taking off. He claimed the noise was "disgraceful" and caused him to lose his hearing due to wearing noise-cancelling headphones. Thibaux was escorted off the runway by security guards after making a complaint about the disturbance. The incident occurred during a high-profile fashion show at the Carriageworks venue, where the music played for about 15 minutes. The event was attended by other attendees who described the noise as "dramatic" but also "embarrassing".

FBI agents are facing a new challenge in maintaining their physical fitness due to concerns over expanding waistlines and lack of mobility. To address this issue, the FBI has introduced compulsory fitness tests for all agents, which include running a mile in 12.5 minutes, sprinting 300 meters in 59 seconds, performing 24 push-ups without stopping, and 35 sit-ups in a minute. The tests aim to assess agents' ability to 'run, fight, and shoot', with older agents receiving slightly longer times. The move follows a growing obesity problem affecting nearly 80 million Americans, with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimating that 1 in 10 adults are obese.

A volcano in Chile's south, known as Volcano Calbuco, erupted suddenly and violently, producing a thick plume of ash and smoke that blocked the sky and forced thousands of people to flee. The eruption occurred near the town of Ensenada, about 10 miles away, and triggered a red alert in the surrounding areas due to its proximity to the city of Puerto Montt. The volcano had been dormant for over 40 years before erupting again, and is considered one of Chile's three most dangerous volcanoes. The eruption caused widespread panic and disruption, with many residents fleeing their homes and seeking shelter elsewhere. The volcano's location, situated 620 miles south of Chile's capital, Santiago, made it a significant concern for those living in the surrounding areas.

Prime Minister David Cameron visited Marston's Brewery in Wolverhampton and delivered an Easter message to Christians, insisting the Coalition had spent five years "trying to lift people up" through policies such as making work pay and encouraging responsibility. The Church of England bishops questioned these policies, citing concerns over language used to describe welfare claimants and implying they are "undeserving". The bishops argued that the wealthiest 10% of households contribute most to deficit reduction, while the richest 1% bear the greatest burden. Cameron defended his policies, saying they aimed to promote compassion, forgiveness, and hard work.

A man named Freddie Gray died in police custody after being arrested in Baltimore, sparking protests and calls for justice. The police department has released limited information about the incident, including a statement from the union saying that officers were justified in pursuing Gray due to a Supreme Court ruling, but protesters argue that excessive force was used. An autopsy found that Gray suffered severe injuries, including a crushed voice box and snapped neck, and that the police used excessive force during his arrest. The police union has stated that the city should settle the case out of court to avoid costs, but protesters claim that this decision ignores the facts of the case. The US Justice Department is also investigating the incident, and several lawmakers have called for charges to be filed against the officers involved.

A 33-year-old airport worker, Brandon Afoa, was awarded $40 million in compensation after a freak runway accident left him paralyzed from the waist down. The accident occurred on December 26, 2007, while Afoa was operating a tug at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. He suffered significant injuries, including a damaged intestine, and underwent extensive surgery. A jury ultimately found the Port of Seattle responsible for failing to maintain a safe working environment, leading to Afoa's long-term disability.

Louis van Gaal has a lunch appointment with Sir Alex Ferguson, expressing a tongue-in-cheek hope that Ferguson will pay for his promise to visit. The Manchester United manager hopes to have genuine and tangible progress to discuss, after a disappointing start to the season. With Manchester City struggling behind them, United are in a strong position to potentially leapfrog into second place. However, their chances of winning the league are not guaranteed, especially with injuries to key players like Daniel Sturridge. Despite this, Van Gaal remains optimistic about his team's chances of finishing in the top four.

A passenger flying from Newcastle Airport to Gatwick was pulled aside by security after staff thought his pease pudding was Semtex, a type of plastic explosive. The 58-year-old part-time actor was surprised to discover that the pease pudding, a traditional North East English dish, was actually just regular food. He admitted to carrying six tubs of the pudding and several Greggs pasties in his luggage, which were later deemed safe. The incident highlights the unpredictable nature of airport security checks.

The West Indies cricket team has been updated for the upcoming Test match against England, with Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite included in the 14-man squad. Sheldon Cottrell, Miguel Cummins, and Veerasammy Permaul were dropped from the initial training camp due to various reasons. Jason Holder has taken over as the new captain, while Denesh Ramdin continues to lead the team. The remaining players include Devendra Bishoo, Kraigg Brathwaite, and several other key players. This lineup change comes ahead of the three-match series starting in Antigua next week.

A 27-year-old sex trade worker was rescued by a dog walker after being held captive for five days by a 43-year-old man in Toronto, Canada. The woman was found bound and naked from the waist down, with multiple sexual assaults inflicted, including "ritualistic actions", and was held at gunpoint. Police say the suspect, Rejean Hermel Perron, was arrested and charged with various crimes, including sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, and forcible confinement. The incident occurred on March 31, and the woman was rescued after a dog walker intervened, using his nail clippers to free her.

A furious row erupted between the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives over claims that David Cameron is plotting to slash support for families through secret plans to cut Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits. The Lib Dems released details of the plans, which include limiting Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits to two children at a cost of £3,500 for a family of three, and announced that the Prime Minister, David Cameron, had flatly rejected the plans. The controversy is the worst row between the two former coalition partners and raises questions about whether they can work together again if the Tories fail to form a majority. The Lib Dems have vowed to block the plan as the price of any future coalition deal.

Sergio Garcia is focusing on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at the Shell Houston Open, despite the Masters being just around the corner. He hopes to complete his career Grand Slam, which includes the Masters, and is determined to make history by becoming the first Spanish golfer to win three majors in succession. Garcia believes that each week brings its own unique challenges, and he aims to stay focused and perform well to achieve his goal. With Rory McIlroy's bid for a third major victory in succession looming, Garcia is prioritizing his own performance over speculation about his future in the sport. The tournament will serve as a test of his ability to adapt to different courses and conditions, and Garcia is confident in his abilities to deliver under pressure.

CNN reported that a video shoot for an internet comedy series in Nepal took a serious turn when a magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck, causing widespread destruction and chaos. A Nepali Pranksters were filming an episode of their hidden camera series when the quake occurred, but instead of panicking, they chose to document the situation. The team kept filming despite the danger, capturing footage of people's reactions to the disaster. The earthquake caused significant damage and injuries, but the Pranksters managed to complete their shot, which has been shared online.

Max Azria's 30,000 sq ft Los Angeles mansion, known as Maison du Solei, boasts numerous luxurious features, including a two-story-tall chandelier, 22 bathrooms, and a whopping $85 million price tag. Located in Holmby Hills, one of the three affluent neighborhoods making up the city's Platinum Triangle, the mansion spans three acres and features a private tennis court, movie theater, and multiple gardens. Built in 1939 by architect Paul Williams, the estate was previously owned by TV writer and novelist Sidney Sheldon and later renovated by Max and his wife Lubov. With 17 bedrooms and 60 rooms to explore, the mansion is a true showstopper, offering unparalleled luxury and opulence.

A 50-year-old woman, Mei Ru, accidentally reversed her car while going shopping with her 53-year-old husband, Song Ming, in Fuzhou, China. He climbed out of the passenger door and stepped back into the car, which she thought was hers, causing her to reverse and knock him to the ground. The incident occurred on a busy street in the city's downtown area. The woman suffered severe injuries, including internal bleeding and broken ribs, and was rushed to the hospital, where she died shortly thereafter due to massive internal bleeding and crushed ribs.

NBC News has retracted its previous report that chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel was kidnapped by forces associated with President Bashar al-Assad, suggesting that the men who took him were likely Sunni rebels. The incident occurred in December 2012, when Engel and two colleagues, Aziz Akyavas and John Kooistra, were kidnapped while reporting in Syria. The captors allegedly convinced them they were government militants, but later admitted to staging the kidnapping for propaganda purposes. Engel claims he was held for five days before being released, and has expressed doubts about the authenticity of the original story.

Lidia Quilligana, a nanny from Danbury, Connecticut, was arrested and charged with first-degree assault of a child under 10 years old and criminal mischief after a video surfaced showing her allegedly beating a 3-year-old girl. The incident occurred when the family installed a nanny cam to monitor their daughter's care, which captured footage of Quilligana choking and burning the girl's legs, arms, and hands on a hot stove. The video was shared with law enforcement, leading to Quilligana's arrest. A defense attorney claims the charges are false, stating that Quilligana knew she was being filmed and had no prior issues with the family.

Michelle Obama was flattered by a 10-year-old girl's compliment during an event where she answered questions about her age. The girl, Anya Brodie, said "You look too young" when Michelle Obama replied "I'm 51." Michelle Obama was touched by the comment and invited Anya up on stage to give her a hug. The exchange was met with laughter and applause as Michelle Obama thanked Anya for the kind words.

A paramedic, Philip Garrod, was caught speeding on his motorbike at 105mph in a 60mph zone, leading to a disciplinary hearing where he falsely claimed a cyclist was injured on the road. Despite this, he was found guilty of misconduct due to his deliberate attempt to deceive authorities about the incident. Garrod claimed he was rushed to work after receiving a false 999 call, but it was later revealed that there was no such call recorded. As a result, he was stripped of his license and fined £650 with six points. The incident highlights concerns over the behavior of some healthcare professionals who prioritize their personal interests over their duties.

A 24-year-old Canadian man named Vin Los gained notoriety after covering his entire body in crude tattoos, earning him a lucrative career as a model despite initial skepticism about his ability to succeed. Despite people doubting his chances, Vin's unique appearance has led to a successful modeling career, landing campaigns for brands such as Garçon Model and featuring in underwear ads. His tattoos, including those on his head, neck, and arms, showcase his bold style and add to his mystique. With 24 tattoos, Vin has become a recognizable figure in the fashion industry, and he plans to continue building his brand and empire through various ventures, including designing wallets and selling them online.

Sir Stirling Moss, widely regarded as the greatest all-round racer, has revealed his unusual daily routine, which includes 77 press-ups and half a bottle of Chardonnay, to celebrate his impressive longevity of 85 years. At 212 races over 14 years, he remains the most successful driver in history. Moss has traded in his high-octane vehicles for a tiny electric car, the Renault Twizy, which he drives around London. His remarkable career spanned decades, earning him numerous accolades, including being knighted in 2000.

A 21-year-old woman from Missouri, Taylor Lynn Fast, was arrested after her 17-month-old daughter Layla was found dead at their home due to alleged self-inflicted injuries caused by a spider bite. The child had severe facial and neck injuries, as well as bruises all over her body, and was pronounced dead shortly after paramedics arrived. The investigation suggests that Fast may have intentionally inflicted the harm on her child, although it is unclear if this was intentional or accidental. Fast is currently being held in jail on charges of endangering the welfare of a child. Her boyfriend has not been named as a suspect.

Florida police officers mourned the death of their colleague, Officer Jared Forsyth, who was accidentally shot while participating in firearms training at a gun range. Forsyth, 33, was a member of the Ocala Police Department for 11 years before being fatally shot in the arm and chest. The incident occurred at the Lowell Correctional Institution's gun range, where Forsyth was wearing a bulletproof vest. The incident remains under investigation, and the other officer involved has not been named. Forsyth's family has expressed sadness over his passing, describing him as "funny" and having a "true servant's heart".

Shaquille Omar Hallisey, a 20-year-old from Cardiff, was sentenced to four years in prison for hitting a stranger over the head with a bottle, leaving the victim with a fractured skull. The incident occurred in a public place, where Hallisey was described as a thug who used a bottle as a weapon. The victim, Matthew Leeke, suffered serious injuries, including cuts to the back of his head and forehead, and was left with a permanent scarring. Hallisey pleaded guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm and was sentenced to four years in prison.

A recent survey found that the average pet spends around 21 hours a week watching TV, with many owners admitting to leaving their pets alone to do so. The most popular shows among pets include "For the Love of Dogs" hosted by Paul O'Grady, followed closely by documentary series like "Natural World". Other favorites include springwatch and soap operas like "EastEnders", but reality shows like "Keeping Up With The Kardashians" and "TOWIE" are less popular among pets. Despite this, many owners feel guilty about leaving their pets alone while they're away, citing concerns about their well-being.

Four sisters, Claire, Emily, Christine, and Lily Vincenti, were separated from their mother, Laura Garrett, due to a dispute over their father, Tomaso Vincenti, whom she accused of abuse. They were taken to Australia and later returned to Italy, sparking a custody battle. The sisters have spoken publicly about their experiences, describing their mother's actions as "selfish" and "cruel". After returning to Italy, they have settled into a new life with their father, Tomaso, and are reportedly happy and content.

Mary Kay Letourneau, a former teacher, and her husband Vili Fualaau, a student, began a romantic relationship when Fualaau was 12 years old, despite her teaching him in sixth grade. Their relationship led to a secret affair, resulting in a pregnancy and a subsequent marriage, which has endured despite challenges, including difficulties caring for their four children. The couple's relationship was marred by issues, including Fualaau's struggles with depression and addiction, and Letourneau's own struggles with guilt and shame. Despite these challenges, they remain committed to each other and have spoken publicly about their experiences. The couple's story has sparked controversy and debate, with some viewing it as a case of "love is pure" versus others seeing it as a crime.

Carl Froch is expected to return to the ring after a year-long absence due to injury, with three potential opponents lined up for his next fight. His manager believes that a fight against James DeGale or Anthony Dirrell could be too easy, while another option is a rematch with Paul Smith. Froch has been training hard and weighed in at 12st 7lbs, indicating his fitness level is returning quickly. The manager is considering a fight against DeGale, who is currently ranked number one in the heavyweight division, but thinks it may be too early for Froch to face him.

Nine-year-old Annabel Beam fell 30ft headfirst into a hollow tree while playing outside, claiming she went to heaven and sat in Jesus's lap while unconscious. Her mother, Christy, says Annabel escaped with minor injuries and miraculous recovery, citing medical evidence and testimony from doctors. Annabel's mother attributes her recovery to a divine intervention, stating that Annabel believed she went to heaven during her fall. The incident occurred in 2011, and Annabel has been experiencing strange visions and dreams since then, which include meeting a guardian angel and seeing Jesus.

The Bradford Bulls have launched an investigation into reports of vandalism at the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park after three cars were broken into and damaged during their recent loss to Hull KR. The team is appealing for witnesses and is working closely with authorities to identify those responsible. The incident has led to concerns about the safety of fans parking in the area. The Bulls are taking steps to prevent such incidents from happening again in the future. The team is committed to maintaining a secure environment for supporters.

A mid-air altercation over legroom on a flight from London Heathrow to Oman resulted in a brawl on Oman Air 102, with one passenger attacking another with a shoe and taking off his shoe as a weapon. The incident occurred due to a disagreement over space on the plane, which led to a confrontation between two passengers. Oman Air's cabin crew intervened and managed to contain the situation, preventing any further harm to fellow passengers. This incident is not the first of its kind, as similar disputes over space have been reported before, including a recent case involving a woman reclining her seat and a man trying to do so. The flight was eventually diverted to land in Jacksonville, where the man was arrested and removed from the aircraft.

A US Navy helicopter was flown within 50 yards of an Iranian observation aircraft over the Persian Gulf, prompting concerns about Iranian control of its forces. The incident occurred while US officials were negotiating a deal with Iran to limit its nuclear program. The US military has expressed concern that the close proximity could lead to a serious incident, despite previous professional interactions between Iranian and US forces in the region. The US is considering a potential protest against Iran, citing the incident as evidence of possible unauthorized action.

A survey found that the "perfect" dog is a mock-up image created by combining various breeds to represent Britain's ideal pet. This image features a mix of characteristics from several breeds, including an English bulldog, King Charles spaniel, Irish setter, and Labrador. The survey revealed that many owners prefer a small, low-maintenance coat, soft ears, and a rounded snout, with some choosing human names like Dave or Lucy. The results showed that regional preferences varied, with Londoners favoring small dogs and East Anglians preferring larger breeds.

Two soldiers, Shaun Smith and Jason Collins, were acquitted of assaulting a civilian in North Yorkshire due to a lenient sentence. The incident occurred after they drank heavily and exchanged insults with the victim, leading to a violent attack. The pair attacked the victim multiple times, with Collins grabbing the man's neck and punching him repeatedly. Despite the severity of the assault, they were given suspended sentences and £1,000 compensation.

Sam Allardyce defended Nigel Pearson after praising him for being "his own man" despite his involvement in several controversies this season. The West Ham manager also expressed admiration for Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson, who has been struggling with poor performances and criticism. Allardyce felt that Pearson's unorthodox approach and refusal to conform to expectations were key factors behind Leicester's success. The pair were reunited when West Ham faced Leicester at the King Power Stadium on Saturday, where they will look to end a goal drought for both teams.

Two 18-month-old twins, Silas and Eli Keslar, drowned while playing near a canal in Yuma, Arizona, after their mother tried to fend off a bee and let go of their stroller, which rolled into the water. The toddler's mother attempted to rescue them, but was unable to retrieve them due to the steep sides of the canal and strong currents. Emergency responders eventually located the twins and took them to a hospital, where they were pronounced dead. Authorities warn that the paths along Yuma canals can be hazardous for pedestrians, particularly for families with young children.

A 29-year-old man from Nevada, USA, suffered severe third-degree burns in a childhood accident at the age of six, resulting in 70% of his body being damaged. Despite facing cruel taunts and bullying due to his appearance, he refused to let fear take over his life and instead chose to become a firefighter. After completing rigorous training, he passed his certification exam and went on to serve as a firefighter, overcoming his fears and proving that he was capable of more than anyone thought possible. Now, he runs a charity to help others with similar experiences, providing funding for programs that support burn victims.

Veteran Robert Clark, a British soldier who survived the Second World War, has seen his life savings dwindle down to just £50,000 after his local council refused to increase funding for his ongoing care. Despite raising £10,000 in just four days through a fundraising appeal, the council has now refused to provide a live-in carer for him due to budget constraints. The 90-year-old veteran, who lives alone in his home in Burnt Oak, North London, relies on a weekly payment of £960 for his care and has relied on his wife's savings to cover this expense. The council claims that moving him into a care home would be too expensive, but the family says it would be a "prison sentence" for their father.

A Conservative building in Aberdeen, Scotland, was sprayed with graffiti by "nationalists" last night, according to a local councillor. The vandalism included a swastika and the word "scum", as well as a white paint mark reading "Q". The incident occurred at a Tory councillor's office, where the councillor claimed it showed the "ugly face of nationalism". The graffiti was reportedly added to the building's window, and similar incidents have occurred in other parts of Scotland in recent weeks.

Lucas Matthysse defeated Ruslan Provodnikov by majority decision in a 12-round super lightweight bout, winning the fight via technical knockout in the fifth round. Matthysse used his three-inch reach advantage to keep Provodnikov at bay, landing several hard punches throughout the fight. Despite Provodnikov's efforts, Matthysse regained control in the fifth round and continued to land clean shots, ultimately securing the victory. The win marked a significant improvement over Provodnikov's previous losses, who lost to Matthysse twice previously. Matthysse expressed relief and gratitude for the win, saying "he did, he hurt me" but praised Provodnikov for being a tough opponent.

Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene has revealed that he uses a carrot-and-stick approach to keep Kimi Raikkonen motivated, having used it to keep his desire to stay with the Maranello marque high despite Lewis Hamilton's recent departure from the team. Raikkonen recently finished second in the Bahrain Grand Prix, demonstrating his ability to perform well under pressure. Arrivabene believes that Raikkonen's desire to remain with Ferrari remains strong, although he acknowledges that Lewis Hamilton may be considering signing with Mercedes. To keep Raikkonen engaged, Arrivabene has implemented a carrot-and-stick strategy, where he offers incentives to maintain good performance. Meanwhile, Ferrari continues to negotiate with Hamilton over a potential new contract, while working to improve their performance to match Mercedes' level.

A new study found that Jamaica tops the list of countries with the highest percentage of female bosses, with nearly 60% of managers holding this position. In contrast, many countries in Europe, particularly those in Eastern Europe and the Middle East, have lower percentages of female bosses. The US ranks 15th globally, with 42.7% of managers being female, despite being considered a "first-world" country. The survey highlights the increasing presence of women in management roles worldwide, but notes that there is still a long way to go in achieving true gender equality.

Australian teenager Violeta Tupuola joined the #kyliejennerchallenge by using a shot glass to pump up her lips to ridiculous proportions, creating a viral sensation on social media. The method, which involves placing a glass over the mouth and sucking in, caused her lips to swell to excessive levels, prompting comparisons to a duck. Many users shared videos and photos of Violeta's transformation, leading to widespread ridicule and criticism. The trend, sparked by Kylie Jenner's infamous pout, has since died down, with some users labeling it "dumb" and "gross".

Stuart McCall, the new manager of Rangers, urged his team to respond immediately to their first defeat of the season, despite being down 2-0 at halftime against Queen of the South. The Ibrox side crashed to their second Championship defeat, which has dropped them to third in the table. McCall maintained that his players' confidence won't be dented by the setback, saying "there will be no confidence factor" come Sunday's match against Raith Rovers. McCall also praised his team's performance in the first half, where they showed signs of improvement, although ultimately fell short. With the play-off push still alive, McCall expects his team to bounce back stronger than ever.

A Los Angeles Police Department officer searched for a person responsible for tagging a police horse named Charly with graffiti while he was patrolling Venice Beach. The tag "RBS" was found on Charly's flank, sparking concerns about the animal's well-being and the potential harm caused by the act. Authorities hope to identify the person behind the tagging through the unique signature "RBS." The LAPD is seeking the public's assistance in tracing the identity of the vandal.

Tony Fernandes, Queens Park Rangers chairman, expressed despair after his team twice threw away a lead against Aston Villa, despite having taken all three points. Fernandes watched the 3-3 draw from afar on his iPhone, experiencing a range of emotions including despair, disappointment, and joy. The match ended with a scoreline of 3-3, with Christian Benteke's hat-trick earning him a draw for Villa. Fernandes praised the performances of Clint Hill and Chris Ramsey, who helped secure the win for the hosts. Despite the loss, Fernandes remained optimistic about the team's chances of staying in the league.

Tottenham's Harry Kane scored his 30th goal of the season in a 3-1 win over Newcastle United, earning him the top spot on the EA Sports Performance Index. This marks another impressive performance from the striker, who is also nominated for the PFA Young Player of the Year award. Kane's goal came in a thrilling round of Premier League action, where other notable performances included Eden Hazard's win against Manchester United and Morgan Schneiderlin's goal for Southampton. Kane is one of several Tottenham players featured in the top 10, alongside fellow nominees like Christian Eriksen and Sergio Aguero. The EA Sports Performance Index ranks players based on their individual contributions to their teams' success, providing an objective measure of their impact on the pitch.

A father in Australia created a humorous t-shirt with a message warning boys to stay clear of his daughter, who looks unimpressed. The image, which went viral on Reddit, features the father wearing a shirt with the words "Stay Clear Boys" emblazoned on it. Despite initial reactions ranging from amusement to ridicule, the post gained over 370,000 likes and 45,000 shares. Some commenters praised the father's creativity, while others criticized him for being overly possessive or controlling.

A 66-year-old woman in Brooklyn was found hanging from a fire escape in her apartment building on Sunday morning, leaving authorities stunned and traumatized by the discovery. She had been suspended for over an hour before being rescued.
