Witnesses reported that the woman appeared to be in a state of distress when she was seen by neighbors, with some believing she may have been a victim of a "Halloween prank." The woman had previously struggled with mental health issues and had difficulty coming out of a dark spot. Authorities have yet to release the woman's identity due to ongoing notifications to her family.

David Raven, a 30-year-old former Shrewsbury and Tranmere player, was the hero of the Scottish football world after scoring the winning goal for Inverness Caledonian Thistle in the Scottish Cup final. The victory marked a rare moment of triumph for the 30-year-old, who had previously struggled with injuries and relegation to lower divisions. Despite the disappointment of losing to Celtic, Raven expressed his relief and pride at the outcome, stating that it was "fantastic" and a "great moment". However, the article also highlights concerns about the state of Scottish football, citing issues such as poor attendance figures and a lack of investment in top-flight teams. The author argues that a restructure of the Scottish football system could help address these problems and restore the sport to its former glory.

Real Madrid's last win was in the Champions League final one year ago, where they defeated Atletico Madrid 4-1. Since then, the two teams have had a long drought without a win, with Atletico emerging victorious in their last seven meetings. This marks the eighth time the two teams have faced each other in the Champions League quarter-finals. Diego Simeone's men have won four times previously, while Carlo Ancelotti's side has failed to win since their last meeting. On Wednesday night's match, Real Madrid lost 4-0 to Atletico Madrid, marking their heaviest defeat in over four years.

A guest can spend a holiday on a secluded island in Brittany, France, known as Ile Louët, where they can stay in a charming 19th-century lighthouse. The island is located amidst Morlaix Bay and offers breathtaking views of the surrounding waters. For a unique experience, guests can rent the entire island for two nights for around £145, or book a cozy cottage for two nights for £200. This isolated retreat is available for adventurous travelers who prefer to self-cater and don't mind ferrying back to the mainland.

Two teenage girls, Kelly McKay and Payge Olds, rescued a 26-year-old Indian man named Mr. Boobesh Palani from Wellington Harbour while he was struggling to stay afloat. The man, who was identified through a photograph posted on social media, was taken to Wellington Hospital, where he sadly passed away. The girls' bravery and quick thinking saved his life, and they were praised by police for their heroic actions. The incident occurred on Monday night, and the man was identified through a search effort involving a fisherman and a newspaper report.

Researchers at the University of Bath and Yale University have developed a new material that can generate clean hydrogen from water, making it easier to produce and store. This breakthrough uses a newly designed molecular catalyst to split water into hydrogen and oxygen, reducing the amount of energy wasted as a byproduct. The innovation has the potential to revolutionize the production of hydrogen fuel, enabling it to be used in cars like the Vauxhall Zafira minivan without relying on fossil fuels. The discovery could contribute to a cleaner and more sustainable energy future, particularly in conjunction with renewable energy sources like solar power.

Labour leader Ed Miliband made his first public appearance in three days after going to ground over the Easter weekend, launching a fresh attack on the Conservative record on the NHS. His campaign trail took place in Bristol, where he spoke to voters and addressed their concerns about waiting times for A&E services. Labour leaders such as David Cameron, Nick Clegg, and Nicola Sturgeon were also seen on the campaign trail, while Nigel Farage campaigned in Kent and Scotland. The Labour leader's decision to appear in a third TV debate against the Conservatives has raised concerns among some Labour MPs.

Saudi airstrikes targeting a military base in Yemen injured at least a half-dozen students and damaged the Al Hamza military base, killing three students, in a strike that occurred while civilians, including children, were present. The strikes come amid ongoing fighting between the Houthis and Saudi-backed forces in Yemen, which has led to widespread destruction and displacement. The US has provided support to Saudi Arabia through airstrikes, including providing guidance on targets, to help minimize civilian casualties. The strikes have resulted in dozens of building damage and the evacuation of 2,500 people from Yemen.

A 38-year-old woman, Julieane Jablonski, has been charged with providing marijuana to a minor and witness tampering after her 19-year-old son, Austin Essig, jumped out of a third-story window while under the influence of a pot brownie she had given him. Essig was hospitalized after the incident and later described the experience as a "trip" that was "far from normal". The incident occurred after Essig consumed a marijuana-laced brownie, which led to a severe reaction that resulted in a non-life-threatening injury. Jablonski was arrested and charged with multiple crimes related to the incident.

Liverpool forward Divock Origi has expressed his excitement to join the club after witnessing the progress of its young players, particularly Jordan Ibe and Raheem Sterling. He believes the team's coaching staff, led by Brendan Rodgers, has played a significant role in their development. Origi credits the support of the fans as another factor in his decision to join the Reds. With seven goals in Ligue 1 this season, Origi feels he has improved significantly since leaving Lille. He hopes to bring a similar level of success to Liverpool, where he can be appreciated and supported by the fans.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry, 28, was suspended for one week after being caught on camera yelling at a parking lot attendant in Arlington, Virginia, for telling her to "lose some weight" and calling her "baby girl". McHenry, known for advocating for women's rights, used her blog to justify her behavior, claiming she was "taking a stand" against sexist commercials focusing on appearance. The incident sparked outrage, with many criticizing her for using derogatory language and making comments about the attendant's appearance. McHenry apologized for her actions, stating she was "furious" and "regrettable", but the backlash continues, with weight bias groups speaking out against her.

A busy mum colours in a child's book while sitting at a table surrounded by crayons, focusing intently on the task. This is a new trend among adults who find solace in colouring, which allows them to relax and express themselves without the distraction of screens. Colouring has become increasingly popular, with many adults seeking out activities that offer a break from the stresses of modern life. Experts attribute this trend to the desire for a creative outlet that is not reliant on technology.

A study has found that the NHS is handing out excessive amounts of suncream and other household items to patients, despite the government's efforts to cut costs. The NHS spent £13 million on suncream in 2014 and £29 million on indigestion pills, with some patients receiving prescriptions for items like toothpaste and multi-vitamins. Critics argue that this is "ludicrous" and that patients are abusing the system by requesting unnecessary prescriptions. The NHS is struggling financially, with a predicted £8 billion gap in its budget by 2020/21, and doctors say that prescribers should focus on prescribing only necessary medications.

Mark Vanhoenacker's book "Skyfaring" explores the fascinating world of commercial aviation through the eyes of a seasoned pilot, sharing stories and anecdotes from his own experiences as a senior first officer with British Airways. The book delves into the psychology behind why pilots are drawn to their jobs despite the risks, and how they cope with stress and pressure. With a unique perspective gained from years of flying, Vanhoenacker reveals the intricacies of air traffic control, the mechanics of flight, and the camaraderie among pilots. His book also touches on the personal side of flying, including the emotional toll of dealing with traumatic events such as the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525.

Manchester City manager Alan Pardew has stated that despite being six points clear of Chelsea at the top of the Premier League table, he does not believe the title is out of their reach. The Eagles' next match is against Manchester City, who have already secured the title with just one game remaining. Pardew has ruled out any major injuries to key players such as Sergio Aguero, Marouane Chamakh, and Jordon Mutch, while captain Mile Jedinak is suspended. With City having gone top with only one game left, Pardew remains confident that his team can still mount a comeback.

Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick has revealed that he wants to pursue a career in motorsport after his playing days are over. Carrick, now 34, has experienced a resurgence in form with Louis van Gaal's side, which has led to a renewed sense of purpose and motivation. He expressed his desire to try his hand at Formula One racing, citing his passion for the sport and enjoyment of watching it. Carrick credits his experience playing under Van Gaal with helping him achieve a "renaissance" in his career.

A non-profit animal welfare charity, Wood Green, is offering a cat-fostering service to help households rid themselves of mouse infestations. The charity claims that cats can deter rodents by producing a scent that scares them away, and they have partnered with cleaning and DIY app Handy to provide a cat-fostering service. To use the service, homeowners must be flexible, patient, and caring towards the animals, and the cats will be provided with food, litter trays, and bedding. The charity aims to help alleviate rodent infestations during the winter months when mice seek shelter indoors.

This weekend's Coachella festival saw a "festival that fashion forgot" with celebrities showcasing outlandish and questionable outfit choices despite being surrounded by others who opted for more subdued styles. Despite the overall theme of the event, some attendees chose to push boundaries with bold and daring fashion statements, such as neon-colored outfits, elaborate headpieces, and outrageous hairstyles. Many celebrities, including Jaden Smith, Kylie Jenner, and Paris Hilton, made headlines for their eclectic and sometimes bizarre fashion choices. Even among those who stuck to more classic styles, there were plenty of examples of outlandish and attention-grabbing outfits.

The trophy room at Sandringham, a Norfolk estate owned by the Queen, has undergone significant changes after being closed for several months. The room, once filled with stuffed rhino heads and gleaming white tusks, has been replaced with "trinkets and bric-a-brac" and has been whitewashed to remove any reminders of its former purpose. This move is seen as a reflection of the shift towards greater political correctness, with many considering it embarrassing for Prince William, who had recently spoken out against the wildlife trade. The removal of the items dates back to the Queen's reign, making them relics of a bygone era.

. £13.50, Waitrose. Finally, if you want to splurge, this one is worth considering. Richer, more complex, and with a slightly more pronounced acidity, it’s perfect for sipping on its own or pairing with a meal.

**The Verdict:** Prosecco is the clear winner in terms of taste, with its crisp, refreshing qualities and affordable price point. However, it’s essential to remember that the quality varies greatly depending on the producer and the specific vintage.

A former Australian doctor, Tareq Kamleh, who joined the Islamic State, is still practicing medicine despite appearing in a propaganda video urging foreign medics to join the terrorist group. The Medical Board of Australia has refused to deregister him due to concerns about his behavior, which includes promoting a "death cult" and engaging in "immoral" activities. Kamleh has been accused by former colleagues of being a "sexually manipulative creep", having multiple romantic relationships with hospital staff, and drinking excessively. Despite these allegations, he remains registered to practice medicine in Australia until September 30.

Two siblings, Piper Kulk, 8, and William Kulk, 9, died in a head-on crash on the NSW Central Coast, along with their grandmother, Helen Boddy, 54, and their parents, Daniel and Chantelle, 31. The incident occurred on Saturday when the car driven by Boddy aqua-planed and swerved into the path of an oncoming ute, resulting in a fatal collision. The siblings and Boddy were all trapped in the wreckage before being released by emergency services. The cause of the crash is under investigation, but it is believed to have been caused by a combination of factors, including heavy rain and inadequate vehicle maintenance. The families have set up a GoFundMe page to raise money for the children's funerals.

A former Italian policeman, Dino Maglio, has been found guilty of raping a 16-year-old Australian girl after luring her to his home via a Couchsurfing website. He spiked her drink with a tranquilizer and then had sex with her despite knowing she was underage. The incident occurred in 2013 and was linked to a year-long investigation into Maglio's activities on the platform, where multiple women have come forward sharing their own similar experiences. The case raises concerns about the safety of travelers using the service, particularly those who may be vulnerable due to language barriers.

Politicians such as Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg, and Natalie Bennett advise against sexting due to its risks, particularly for younger individuals. They express concerns about the potential consequences of sharing explicit content online. The examples cited include the scandals involving Brooks Newmark and Iain Corby, who both faced disciplinary action for exchanging lewd messages. Sexting can lead to embarrassment, damage to reputation, and even legal repercussions.

A 48-year-old man, Tracy Walters, died after his 4x4 vehicle veered off the M1 motorway and hit a tree while returning from a trip with his wife, 48-year-old Tracy Walters, who suffered severe injuries. Walters, a driving test examiner, was charged with her murder two months after her death, alleging that conflict over sex was a main reason for their marital collapse. His defense claims that his sex drive was higher than hers and that he was taking medication that caused drowsiness at the time of the crash. Walters denied murder, saying he fell asleep at the wheel due to medication. The trial continues, with prosecutors presenting evidence of abuse allegations against Walters and his wife.

Manchester Airport was forced to temporarily suspend flights due to a reported drone sighting in the area, causing disruption to hundreds of travellers. The drone was spotted buzzing around the airport, prompting concerns that it could collide with a passenger jet. Flights were halted for approximately 20 minutes before being resumed after a police search failed to find any evidence of the drone's presence. The incident highlights the growing concern over unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which have become increasingly popular for aerial photography but pose a risk to air travel.

Chinese authorities have developed a new cyberattack called the "Great Cannon", which uses a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) technique to disrupt internet traffic to specific websites, including those that provide access to Western news sources. The Great Cannon is designed to target servers outside of China, including in the US, and has been tested on several occasions, including in March. Researchers from the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab and other organizations claim that the Great Cannon is a powerful tool that could be used to censor content and silence critics. The development of the Great Cannon is seen as a threat to freedom of speech and access to information, particularly in light of China's increasing restrictions on dissent and criticism.

A Spanish airport, Ciudad Real, was built in 2009 at a cost of €1 billion and was expected to serve both Madrid and the coastal region. However, after three years of operation, it was closed due to financial difficulties and eventually sold for £86 million. The airport's terminal remains abandoned, with no flights taking off or landing, and a large area of the runway is now used for storage. Despite efforts to sell it, no buyer has emerged, leaving the airport to stand idle.

A New York City police detective, Patrick Cherry, was fired after a viral video showed him yelling at an Uber driver, calling him "d***" and making obscene comments. The incident sparked widespread outrage, with many condemning Cherry's behavior as unacceptable and treating him poorly. An investigation found that Cherry had failed to treat the driver with courtesy and respect, and that his actions were "bad enough" to warrant disciplinary action. The incident led to Cherry being placed on modified duty and transferred out of the Joint Terrorism Task Force. A passenger shared the video on social media, describing the scene as "abused" and expressing support for the driver.

Edwin van der Sar, a former Manchester United goalkeeper, has expressed his confidence that Louis van Gaal will bring the "glory days" back to the club. The former manager is optimistic about the team's chances of challenging for the Premier League title, despite being likely to finish fifth or sixth this season. With a strong squad and a renewed sense of purpose under Van Gaal, United are poised to compete against their arch-rivals Chelsea on Saturday. The Red Devils' recent six-match winning streak suggests they are in top form, and Van Gaal's ability to add key signings could be crucial in securing a top-four spot. If United can hold onto their current form, they may be able to push for a Champions League spot.

Bournemouth drew 2-2 with Sheffield Wednesday despite trailing to a Kieran Lee sucker punch in the 36th minute. The Cherries' hopes of keeping top spot in the division were dashed when Chris Maguire converted a penalty in stoppage time to level the score. However, Bournemouth ultimately fell behind again, this time to Yann Kermorgant's equalizer. The match ended in controversy when Simon Francis was sent off for two yellow cards, leaving Bournemouth to settle for a draw. Despite the disappointment, the Cherries' fans were seen celebrating a thrilling match that will be remembered as one of the best of the season.

A 18-year-old woman named Billy-Anne Huxham was kidnapped at knife-point by her ex-boyfriend Carl Garry Chapman, 32, while she was being held captive in his home. She was found by police after making contact with a family member, and was subsequently released when her ex-partner was arrested and charged with various offenses. Chapman had used a firearm to subdue the victim and was later found in a nearby abandoned vehicle. Huxham was left with injuries, including bruises and a machete wound, and was eventually released by police after a police chase.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman has urged his players to "forget" about other teams and focus on themselves to improve their scoring record, which has been stunted by recent performances. The Saints' stellar season has stalled, but Koeman believes his team can turn things around with renewed effort. With striker Graziano Pelle struggling to find form, Koeman may recall Senegalese winger Sadio Mane to the starting lineup. To achieve success, Koeman emphasizes the importance of improving their ability to create scoring opportunities. Despite being in a tight battle for European spots, Southampton remain in contention for a top-six finish.

A large number of goldfish have invaded Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado, due to pet dumping, and are now threatening the local aquatic ecosystem. Wildlife officials warn that the non-native species can cause disease outbreaks and create competition for resources, and consider electroshocking or draining the lake as a solution. The lake is approximately 12 acres in size and has already seen significant growth, with estimates suggesting over 3,000 to 4,000 goldfish. Officials are advising against retrieving the fish and instead plan to take them to a local raptor rehabilitation program.

Everton's disappointing Europa League campaign may not be solely attributed to the competition, according to goalkeeper Tim Howard. Despite playing 10 European games, the Toffees have struggled to find consistency in the Premier League, with a four-game unbeaten run ending in defeat. Howard believes the team's performance is more than just the Europa League, stating "luck hasn't gone their way" and they need to focus on achieving their goals in the Premier League. The team faces a tougher task ahead, as they aim to finish in the top half of the table. With injuries to key players like Leon Osman and Bafetimbi Gomis, Howard is determined to help the team overcome their struggles.

The Atlanta Hawks defeated the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night, helping them end their franchise record 57th win of the season. Forward Paul Millsap suffered a right shoulder injury in a collision with Brooklyn's Earl Clark during the first half, leaving him out for the remainder of the game. The Hawks' 8-point lead was eventually ended when they trailed by 4 points with 1:52 left in the second half. Despite the setback, the Hawks still managed to secure their 57th win of the season.

A new study by Ofcom reveals that the average 4G mobile phone speed in the UK is lower than expected, with an average of 2.5 times faster than the 3G service, but slower than initially promised. The study found that 4G speeds in the UK are likely to slow down due to increased usage, with many people connecting to the network. The results come after a survey of 120,000 smartphones in five cities showed that download speeds decreased by 12.5% and calls took longer to connect. The study's findings suggest that the rollout of 4G services may not live up to the hype, despite initial claims from mobile phone companies.

Jimmy Anderson was awarded a silver cap by Mike Atherton to mark his 100th Test match for England. This achievement is a testament to his exceptional career, joining a select group of fast bowling centurions such as Courtney Walsh, Glenn McGrath, and Chaminda Vaas. Anderson's impressive record makes him part of a prestigious club alongside these legends. The occasion was marked with a tribute to Richie Benaud, who passed away recently, and both teams showed respect by wearing black armbands. The ceremony highlighted the importance of teamwork and the value of playing for the national team over personal gain.

Ellia Beasley, a 22-year-old model from New Milton, Hampshire, got a tattoo of the lyrics "scream your heart out" from the song "Rooftops" by Lost Prophet in 2012. The tattoo was meant to express her love for the song, but it ended up being a source of shame due to the band's subsequent conviction for child abuse. After discovering the truth about the band member's actions, Ellia felt guilty and regretted having the tattoo. A tattoo artist eventually created a new design that covered the original lyrics, and Ellia has since spoken positively about the experience.

A taxi driver in Shenyang, China, known as "Uncle Teng," has gained international recognition for taking thousands of selfies with passengers, earning him a record-breaking 30,000 likes on social media. Starting his career 10 years ago, Uncle Teng would pick up tourists and offer them a free ride, but instead, he'd ask for a photo and often receive a generous tip. His unique approach has made him a beloved figure in the city, with many passengers commenting on how his infectious smile brightens up their day. Now, he's set to be awarded the Shanghai Big World Jinisi Record for his remarkable achievement.

Mindy Kaling, a comedian and actress, has denied knowing anything about her brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam's decision to pretend to be African American to get into medical school. Chokal-Ingam, 38, revealed in his book "Almost Black" that he transformed his appearance to gain admission to medical school in the late 1990s. A representative for Kaling stated she was estranged from Chokal-Ingam for years and denies knowing about his decision. Chokal-Ingam claims he was aware of his brother's actions and expressed shame over them, stating he wanted to prove that affirmative action policies are flawed.

A 53-year-old woman, Julie McKenzie, initially visited her GP about her nagging back pain, which turned out to be due to mild scoliosis. An MRI scan revealed that her spine had a slight curvature, which was confirmed to be caused by a tumor in her coccyx. After undergoing surgery to remove the tumor, Julie was told that she had a benign tumor, but the exact nature of the tumor was unclear. Despite ongoing follow-up care, Julie continues to experience back pain, although she believes that her life has improved significantly since the surgery.

A French Bulldog in California left alone in a car honked its horn repeatedly, causing concern among witnesses. Ryan Burns captured footage of the incident on his camera phone, which showed the dog standing with its front paws firmly on the horn. The dog's owner disputes the claim, stating that the dog was well-cared for and never left alone without supervision. The incident sparked outrage, with many viewers criticizing the dog's behavior as "animal cruelty."

Photographer Anthony Barbour, 33, from Liverpool, creates stunning 360-degree photographs by spending hours capturing individual planets at various British locations, such as Sefton Park, One Shopping Centre, and Mudeford Beach. Using a Canon 1100d DSLR and specialized equipment, he stitches together the 50 photos to create unique, mind-bending images. Barbour finds inspiration in unexpected places, including villages and beaches, and believes that photography helps him cope with a recent illness. His work showcases his creativity and skill, making him a talented artist.

A 21-year-old son of a Labour councillor, Waheed Ahmed, was arrested at the Turkish border with eight of his relatives and deported back to the UK. His parents, Shakil Ahmed, a councillor in Rochdale, and a university student, claimed their son was on holiday but later denied any involvement in terrorism. Six others, including four adults and two minors, were arrested and held at airports, with five houses searched in connection with the attempt to enter Syria. The individuals were all released without charge due to lack of evidence suggesting an imminent threat to British communities.

A 32-year-old man, Carlos Colina, has been charged with murder in connection with the dismemberment and burial of a 26-year-old man named Jonathan Camilien. Authorities discovered the remains in a duffel bag in Cambridge, which led to Colina being arrested on charges of assault and battery causing serious bodily injury. The two men had known each other previously, and police found additional body parts in an apartment building near the Cambridge Police Department headquarters. The investigation revealed that the remains belonged to Camilien, who was murdered, and that Colina was linked to the crime through their prior relationship.

Huddersfield secured a 38-14 Super League victory over Catalans Dragons, thanks to a seven-try romp that saw in-form winger Aaron Murphy score twice. The in-form winger had a standout performance, scoring twice in the match, and helped Huddersfield secure a much-needed win after a three-match losing run. Murphy's efforts were rewarded with a player of the month award for February and March. The Giants' victory marked a significant improvement on their previous performances, which included a 20-point loss to St Helens. With Murphy's impressive display, Huddersfield ended a long losing streak.

A group of individuals poured gasoline on a car at a gas station in South Los Angeles, setting it on fire. The suspects then attempted to carjack the vehicle before fleeing with the fuel tank. The incident occurred when the driver, whose identity has not been released, became involved in an argument with the suspects over the car. The fire was extinguished without anyone being injured, but the car was severely damaged. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson.

Hillary Clinton's Twitter account has been found to have a significant number of fake followers, with estimates suggesting around 2 million out of 3.6 million possible followers are "active" users. Two popular online auditing tools, StatusPeople and TwitterAudit.com, have reported that nearly 44% of her followers are fake, with some estimates as high as 54,000 being completely inactive. This raises questions about the authenticity of her online presence, particularly given her claims of being a champion of "everyday Americans."

Andrea Dossena, a former Liverpool player, was arrested on suspicion of shoplifting at Harrods in Knightsbridge on Tuesday. He was accused of stealing £40,000 worth of goods, which he allegedly attempted to conceal in his jacket pocket. Dossena was later bailed to a date in late April pending further enquiries. The incident occurred during a match between Liverpool and Manchester United in March 2009, where Dossena scored a goal.

A rescue team freed nearly 100 dogs from a dark and filthy barn in Tennessee, where they had been living in extreme conditions for an unknown period. The dogs, mostly adult breeds, were found to be severely malnourished and suffered from severe health issues, including heart problems and infections. Despite initial fear and aggression upon being approached, the dogs showed signs of relief and joy when released outdoors, with some even shooting their noses towards the sunlight. The property owner, 64-year-old Caroline Irby, was charged with animal cruelty and faces multiple felony charges related to the incident.

Michael Easy, 29, from Southampton, Hampshire, was jailed for 15 months in 2013 for assaulting a woman at a party and then again for breaching a restraining order and assaulting prison officers in 2022. He posed on Facebook in a silver wig and Dame Edna Everage-style sunglasses, taunting police with the photo, sparking a nationwide manhunt. Easy was released from prison in December 2021 after serving 15 months for assaulting a woman in 2013, but reoffended by breaching a restraining order and assaulting prison officers in 2022. He faces up to four months in prison for breaching the order and assaulting two prison guards.

A 18-year-old Long Island resident, Harold Ekeh, has been accepted into all eight Ivy League colleges, including Yale, after submitting essays that described his struggles adapting to life in America. His parents, former Target clerks, played a significant role in encouraging him to pursue higher education despite initial doubts. Harold's achievement has been hailed as the American Dream, but he remains humble, stating that he worked hard and took every opportunity that came his way. He plans to attend Yale, where he hopes to study neurosurgery and pursue a career in medicine.

Prime Minister David Cameron revealed in an interview that he and his wife Samantha were "falling apart" due to the immense pressure of caring for their son Ivan, who was born with Ohtahara Syndrome, a rare brain disorder requiring constant care and attention. Their marriage was put to the test as they struggled to cope with the challenges of raising a child with such a condition. The couple's struggles led to feelings of loneliness and isolation, and they eventually became "shattered", with Samantha describing the experience as a "nightmare". The revelation sparked widespread sympathy and support for the Camerons, who have since spoken publicly about the difficulties of balancing their public duties with their role as parents.

Numerous radio dramas, including Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour, have had their last minutes removed from the iPlayer service due to technical issues caused by the BBC's automated recording system. Frustrated listeners claim that the problem has ruined their viewing experience, leaving them feeling "irritating", "annoying", and "frustrating". The issue affects over 57 million requests made to the iPlayer service each month, with many users complaining about being unable to access entire programs after they've finished. The BBC has blamed the system for the problem, stating that it causes the start and end times of programs to shift, but this is not a new issue for the corporation.

In April 2015, several countries experienced severe drought affecting residents and businesses. The drought has been particularly challenging for Kenya, where President Uhuru Kenyatta was replaced by Muhammadu Buhari. Meanwhile, scientists have developed a device that can fit into insect bodies, allowing them to study their neural systems. A typhoon named Typhoon Maysak threatens an island nation in Southeast Asia.

Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge faces a fight to be fit for their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after being left out of the team due to an injury problem. He was left out of Monday night's Barclays Premier League clash against Newcastle United. The match is scheduled for Sunday, which means Sturridge will not play until then. His absence has left the Reds' chances of winning the FA Cup slim, but they remain hopeful of making it into the Champions League. With Manchester City trailing behind them in the Premier League, Liverpool must win their game against Newcastle to stay in contention.

A teenage burglar, Thomas Buckett, fell through a roof of a school's tuck shop and broke his neck, leaving him seriously injured. He was part of a group of teenagers who attempted to break into the building on a Sunday, and later tried to jump onto a concrete floor after falling. The incident led to a lawsuit against the local authority, which has resulted in a massive £150,000 legal bill for the family. Thomas, now 21, faces a huge bill due to his injuries, including life-changing head injuries and skull fractures, and is being forced to undergo extensive medical treatment.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea manager, believes he is improving in various aspects of his job despite facing criticism for his honesty with the media. He claims to be getting better at managing the team and preparing games, but acknowledges that his frankness can sometimes lead to controversy. Mourinho has accumulated fines for making false accusations, such as against Stoke City, and admits that his tendency to speak truthfully about the game may be a weakness. Despite this, he feels that his improvement is evident in other areas of his management. However, he insists that he will continue to avoid hypocrisy when speaking to the media.

In Ferguson, Missouri, a predominantly black suburb, two new members of the city council were elected, bringing a significant increase in African-American representation. The election comes nearly a month after the release of a Department of Justice report detailing a culture of racism and abuse in the city, prompting voter turnout to triple. The election saw a substantial increase in voter turnout, with 29.4% of registered voters casting their ballots, compared to 12.3% in the previous election. The newly elected council members include Wesley Bell, a lawyer and criminology professor, who won in a landslide victory in Ward 3, while Ella Jones and Brian Fletcher also secured seats in other wards.

Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly in North Carolina on July 25 after knocking out Jose Mourinho's side in the Champions League last season. The Blues will continue their preparations for the Premier League title by playing three more friendlies in the US, including a match against the New York Red Bulls. This marks the end of their European campaign, which saw them knock out Mourinho's side in the last 16 stage following a 2-2 draw. Chelsea will celebrate their 0-0 draw at Arsenal earlier in the season. The Blues' next opponents include Paris Saint-Germain, Barcelona, and Fiorentina in the International Champions Cup.

Burnley manager Sean Dyche has called on his teammates to share the goalscoring burden to keep the team in the Premier League, despite struggling striker Danny Ings being out of sorts. Ings has failed to score in his last eight matches, and Dyche wants others to step up to relieve the pressure. The team has scored only one goal in their last seven matches, and Dyche believes it's unfair to put the entire burden on Ings. He also mentions that Burnley's recent performances suggest that the team can create chances without relying solely on Ings. With Ings struggling, Dyche wants his teammates to contribute to the team's survival.

English photographer John Chapple has traveled extensively around the world, capturing stunning panoramic images using a film camera. His work includes landscapes such as grassy fields in England, major US cities like New York City, and sandy beaches in Australia. Chapple's photography style features dramatic shots of natural wonders like mountains, deserts, and coastlines. With a passion for preserving the world's beauty, Chapple aims to create images that will be shared with future generations.

A celebrity handbag has sparked controversy due to its unusual designs, including logos and images that may be considered off-putting or insensitive. Many celebrities, including Madonna and Rihanna, have been accused of pushing the boundaries of what is considered acceptable in the world of fashion. Their use of bejeweled luxury accessories, such as diamonds and guns, has led to criticism from some quarters. Despite being banned in several countries, these bags remain popular among some fans, who see them as statements about rebellion and individuality.

ABC's World News Tonight evening newscast has officially overtaken underfire rival NBC's Nightly News in the ratings war for the first time in more than five and a half years. The shift occurred due to NBC's 288 consecutive week winning streak, which ended when anchor Brian Williams received a six-month suspension for misleading viewers about his coverage of the Iraq War. This marks the first time the ratings war has seen a top spot change since September 2009. The drop in ratings is attributed to Williams' suspension, but it's unclear what impact this may have on anchor Lester Holt's future on the show.

Robert Downey Jr., the actor playing Iron Man in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, has been accused of making a racist remark about Mexican director Alejandro González Iñárritu during an interview. The incident occurred while promoting his latest film, Avengers: Age of Ultron. Downey Jr. responded to criticism by stating that Iñárritu's work is "basic" and "profoundly wrong", implying that he believes Iñárritu's films promote a conservative ideology. This followed a series of other controversies surrounding the actor's behavior, including a previous incident where he walked out of an interview with Channel 4 after discussing his past struggles with addiction.

A prisoner claimed that the 25-year-old Freddie Gray, who died in police custody, was trying to injure himself in a police van, citing a leaked affidavit that stated he was "banging against the walls" and "intentionally trying to injure himself". The prisoner, who was jailed for violating a restraining order, said he couldn't see what Gray was doing due to a metal partition separating them. An investigation by the Washington Post revealed that the prisoner's claim was disputed by officials, who said Gray was actually restrained and suffered severe spinal injuries. The prisoner obtained a warrant to search an arresting officer's clothing for possible traces of Gray's DNA, which was used to confirm the prisoner's account.

A private wedding celebration between Sir Paul McCartney and Heather Mills took place in 2002, but it was marred by controversy due to the couple's previous marriage and separation. The wedding was attended by 300 guests, including other famous musicians like Ringo Starr and Chrissy Hynde, and was shrouded in secrecy until the invitations were released. The couple posed for several photographs, including a mock striptease scene, before departing for their honeymoon. Their marriage ended in divorce in 2008, and the couple has since become embroiled in a bitter custody battle over their children.

Sebastian Vettel has expressed his determination to ensure the return of a long-standing ritual at Ferrari, having just secured their first win in 35 races. He attended a factory visit where he met with teammates and staff, including Britta Roeske, who raised a Ferrari flag at the entry gate. Vettel shared stories about the significance of the ritual and its history, highlighting the team's desire to revive it. Despite facing stiff competition from rival teams like Mercedes, Vettel remains optimistic about Ferrari's chances of achieving success. With a strong package and car, Vettel aims to maintain a positive momentum going into the next races.

Iona Costello, a 51-year-old mother from Long Island, and her 9-year-old daughter Emily were found safe and well in New York City's Upper West Side neighborhood after being missing since March 30. They were identified by the front desk manager of the hotel where they stayed while visiting Manhattan. The pair had been traveling together when they vanished, and their car was found in a parking garage on 42nd Street. Iona's husband, George Costello, passed away in 2012 due to a heart attack, and she had been under stress due to a legal battle with four of his adult children.

A Nigerian Christian refugee prayed for his life while on a rubber dinghy carrying 100 African migrants across the Mediterranean, prompting a violent confrontation between the group and a Muslim crew member. The incident resulted in the death of 12 Christians, while others were thrown into the sea. An investigation found that the Muslim crew members had become agitated due to the Christian's prayer, leading to a violent attack. The incident has raised concerns about the safety and treatment of migrants attempting to cross the Mediterranean. The incident highlights the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Africa, where thousands of migrants have died or gone missing trying to reach Europe.

A four-month-old baby named Evan Summerfield died from meningitis just 12 hours after laughing for the first time, leaving his family devastated. The baby's parents, Shannon and Kris, were shocked and confused by the rapid progression of his illness, which included a rash and fever. Evan's grandmother described him as being taken away from them in an instant, saying "it seemed like in a heartbeat". The family has set up a fundraising page to support the costs of his funeral and to raise awareness about meningitis and septicaemia.

A 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan named Krista Dotzenrod successfully caught a foul ball while drinking a beer during a game against the San Diego Padres on Saturday afternoon. She was sitting in her seat in the second row near third base when the ball fell into her cup. After taking a sip of her beer, she chugged it down and wished the Cubs good luck before posting a photo of herself with the ball on social media. Her actions sparked widespread attention, with many fans asking if they could go on a date with her.

Erik Meldik, a Czech man, was subjected to a painful comeuppance after pretending to put his girlfriend's dog in a washing machine, only to be left with a nasty situation when his girlfriend, Dominika Petrinova, glued him to a chair naked. The prank went viral, but Petrinova sought revenge by gluing wax strips to a chair, leading to a humiliating experience for Meldik. The incident sparked widespread laughter and attention, earning them both the nickname "The Viral Brothers" in their home country. Meldik suffered a painful ordeal, including ripping himself free from the chair, leaving behind some skin and hair.

Hull City are considering selling midfielder Nedum Onuoha due to his contract expiring soon, with several clubs interested in signing him. He has already attracted attention from QPR, Everton, and West Ham United, while also being linked to other teams such as Stoke City and Catania. Onuoha has been playing regularly for QPR under manager Chris Ramsey and has impressed in the Premier League. Meanwhile, Hull City are holding talks with Onuoha about a potential transfer, although it remains unclear if he will stay at the club. Additionally, West Bromwich Albion are also monitoring the situation regarding Victor Anichebe, who is expected to be sold this summer.

Cereal cafes, porridge pop-ups, and toastie restaurants are becoming increasingly popular in London, with the latest addition being the Oshun Café, serving £6 bowls of Brazilian superfood acai berries. This new eatery, located in the capital, offers four variations of berry bowls, including the Oshun Tang, Oshun Kong, Oshun Maya, and Oshun Native. The café aims to promote the benefits of acai berries, which are rich in antioxidants, vitamins, and minerals, and are believed to aid in weight loss and improve overall health. With its unique blend of flavors and ingredients, the Oshun Café is expected to attract customers looking for a healthy and delicious meal option.

A haunting image shows the partially-submerged remains of the St Ivan Rilski Church in the Zhrebchevo reservoir, near the town of Tvardica, Bulgaria. This is the only remaining evidence of the former settlement of Zapalnya, which was swallowed by an artificial lake 50 years ago. The town's residents were forced to leave their homes and live elsewhere, leaving behind remnants like this church, which has been submerged underwater since 1965. The church is a poignant reminder of the devastating impact of human actions on the environment.
Benzema, Carvajal.

The Premier League match between Everton and Southampton is scheduled for this Saturday, with Everton facing a late fitness test for striker Romelu Lukaku due to a hamstring injury. Midfielder Darron Gibson is also a doubt, while goalkeeper Fraser Forster is out for the season after knee surgery. Southampton's Steven Davis is a doubt for the same reason, having suffered a groin injury on international duty. The teams have a head-to-head record, with Everton winning only once before, most recently in November 1996. This match marks a significant opportunity for both sides to gain valuable points, with Southampton looking to break their recent slump and maintain their top-four hopes.

Yoshinori Muto, a 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward, is considering joining Chelsea in the Premier League despite an offer from the club. The offer is reportedly worth around £4 million, but Muto wants to consider other options before making a decision. Muto has praised Real Zaragoza coach Ranko Popovic, who managed him in his debut season, saying he has "something special" and "a noble" personality. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has expressed interest in signing Muto, citing his intelligence, speed, and confidence, but has stated that commercial considerations may influence the transfer decision.

A supporter of former Wales goalkeeper Jason Brown was successfully prosecuted for racially abusing him while he was playing for Dartford in a Vanarama Conference fixture at Bristol Rovers. John Wild, from Wotton-under-Edge in Gloucestershire, was given a three-year banning order and ordered to carry out community service, pay compensation, and cover court fees after being found guilty of the abuse. Brown welcomed the outcome, criticizing the Football Association and other organizations for not taking action against the perpetrator. However, he praised the police for bringing the case to a satisfactory conclusion.

Scott Turner Schofield, a prominent figure in the LGBTQ+ community, will make a significant television appearance starting in May. He will play a recurring role on the daytime soap opera "The Bold and the Beautiful" as Nick, a mentor to the character of Maya Avant, a transgender woman. This marks Schofield's first major television appearance as a transgender actor. Schofield, an author and speaker, has been advocating for greater representation of transgender characters in media.

A study warns that children may suffer severe injuries in rugby due to the nature of the sport, particularly during scrums and tackles. Experts, including Professor Allyson Pollock, a public health specialist at Queen Mary, University of London, argue that the lack of adequate injury surveillance and prevention measures is alarming. According to Pollock, only 1 in 8 children who participate in rugby will suffer injuries serious enough to require multiple training sessions or matches. The UK government's plans to increase funding and participation in rugby at school, despite concerns about safety, are deemed "extremely worrying" by Pollock.

Tiger Woods, a 14-time major winner, faces significant challenges after returning from a wrist injury, but has vowed to return to the PGA Tour at the Players Championship. He was spotted meeting with Yao Ming, a 7ft 6in former NBA star, who offered golfing tips at Nike's headquarters in Shanghai. Woods has played only three tournaments this year, including a return to the US Masters, where he showed signs of improvement. His return is expected to alleviate concerns about a lingering wrist issue that forced him to miss several events. Woods will compete in the Memorial at Muirfield Village starting June 4.

Andy Murray faced a scare during his quarterfinal match against 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem at the Miami Open, losing 3-6, 6-4, 6-1 in an hour and three quarters. Despite the loss, Murray reached the semi-finals of the tournament, where he faces Tomas Berdych in the next round. To ensure he doesn't lose any further ground in the world rankings, Murray has been given extra preparation time to focus on his tennis business. With his fiancée watching from the stands, Murray praised Thiem as a "strong guy" and acknowledged that he needs to improve to stay ahead of the pack. Murray also expressed confidence in his own abilities, stating that he'll continue to work hard to climb the rankings.

Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany revealed that his mother prevented him from joining Manchester United at the age of 17 due to her insistence that he complete his education before pursuing a career in football. Kompany joined Anderlecht at a young age and was highly sought after by Manchester United, who offered him a contract. However, his mother ultimately decided to keep him in Belgium, prioritizing his studies over football. Now, as captain of Manchester City, Kompany credits his decision with helping him achieve success. With Manchester City set to face their arch-rivals Manchester United, Kompany is determined to lead his team to victory.

The Duchess of Cambridge's style is being criticized by leading author Margaret Atwood, who claims she dresses "uneventfully" and follows the advice of others. Women across the globe admire Kate's sense of style, but Atwood believes this is due to her careful consideration of what to wear rather than any innate flair. Atwood says Kate's fashion choices are often dictated by advisers, which may explain why some critics dismiss her as an "uneventful" dresser. Despite this, Kate's style is still widely admired, particularly among women around the world.

A 51-year-old cyclist, Martyn Uzzell, died after being thrown into the path of a four-inch deep pothole on a busy road in North Yorkshire. The road, on the A65 near Giggleswick, had been inspected multiple times before his death, but the council failed to take action despite receiving warnings about its hazardous condition. An inquest found that the pothole was the cause of the incident, and the council accepted no liability for the tragedy. The widow of the cyclist has reached an out-of-court settlement with the council, but the local authority remains unapologetic about its handling of the situation.

Real Madrid's Cristiano Ronaldo scored five goals in a 9-1 win over Granada, keeping their title hopes alive. He achieved this feat for the first time in his career. Ronaldo's impressive performance earned him widespread coverage in Spanish sports papers. The match against Granada was part of a busy weekend for Ronaldo, who also scored three goals in a previous match. Barcelona's defeat to Celta Vigo was marred by a diving header from French defender Jeremy Mathieu.

Holland manager Guus Hiddink slammed his own supporters for booing Andres Iniesta during their 2-0 victory over Spain on Tuesday night. The Spanish coach was unimpressed with the treatment of Iniesta, who started on the bench despite being given the opportunity to come on. Hiddink described the incident as a "disgrace" and questioned why Iniesta was subjected to such treatment. The victory marked a much-needed boost for Hiddink, who has faced criticism for his tactics and team selection. The Dutch side's performance was praised by Hiddink, who noted that they had shown "guts" and were able to overcome mistakes to secure the win.

Hillary Clinton's aide Huma Abedin spent a relaxing family day in New York with her husband Anthony Weiner and two-year-old son Jordan, enjoying a meal at Tortaria, a Mexican eatery near their apartment. The 38-year-old was spotted wearing a baseball cap and sunglasses, relishing a meal with her family. Abedin had previously dined at Chipotle, but this outing marked a departure from her usual fast-food routine. The family's decision to skip Chipotle was seen as a sign of their desire for something more upscale. Abedin's husband Anthony Weiner, a disgraced former congressman, was also spotted eating at Tortaria.

Celebrities such as Bianca Westwood, Rob Lee, Clare Balding, and others have shown their support for The Bobby Moore Fund for Cancer Research UK through Football Shirt Friday, a charity event where fans wear their favorite football shirts in memory of the late 1966 World Cup-winning captain Bobby Moore. The event aims to raise money for bowel cancer research. The campaign kicks off annually in April to coincide with Bowel Cancer Awareness Month. Participants can choose to wear any vintage or current football shirt, regardless of affiliation, to participate. By doing so, supporters aim to raise funds for the Bobby Moore Fund.

QUINTON "RAMAGE" JACKSON, a former light-heavyweight champion, returns to the Octagon after a two-year absence, admitting he's been through a challenging time but feels motivated by his desire to prove himself as a formidable opponent. He faces Fabio Maldonado in a catchweight bout at UFC 186 in Montreal. Jackson, known for his intense preparation and mental toughness, believes the fight will showcase two big, physical opponents. Despite being in a tough spot, Jackson hopes to put on a show for the fans and prove they wanted him to fight. This is Jackson's second stint in the UFC since stepping back from Bellator.

A pregnant woman was saved after her partner dived under a capsized boat in the English Channel to retrieve an emergency flare, while she clung to the hull of the overturned trimaran. The woman's partner ensured her safety before tying a rope around himself to dive back to the surface. The woman was eventually rescued by a Coastguard boat, which located her and took her to the hospital. She was treated for cold shock and shaken but unharmed.

A 17-year-old teenager who had been undergoing chemotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma at Connecticut Children's Medical Center has completed treatment and returned home after being placed in the hospital due to concerns about her safety. The teenager, identified as Cassandra, had run away from the hospital earlier this month after deciding she didn't want to continue treatment. A judge initially ordered her into custody, citing her risk of harming herself or others. However, a new ruling has ended the temporary custody order, allowing Cassandra to return home. The teenager's mother and attorneys have appealed the decision, but it appears that Cassandra will remain in the community.

A 10-year-old Minnesota boy whose body was found in the Mississippi River over the weekend was arrested and charged with second-degree murder. Pierre Collins, the father, was taken into custody on suspicion of the crime, which occurred less than a month after he appeared at a vigil pleading for his safe return. The boy had been missing since March 18, and his body was discovered on Saturday near the river. Collins' wife, Yamah, was also arrested and taken into custody, although she was not cuffed.

Efforts to rescue survivors from beneath the rubble of Kathmandu continue, with grievers gathering to cremate thousands of victims of the devastating earthquake that struck on Saturday. The death toll has risen to over 4,000, with many families attempting to honor their loved ones with traditional Hindu rituals. Cremations are taking place alongside the Bagmati River, where bodies are being burned amidst the ruins of the city. The nation is grappling with a grim reality, with many residents forced to live beneath the rubble or in makeshift shelters.

A horse named Cody became stuck in a muddy ditch while competing in the Grand National at Aintree, prompting fire crews to respond with over an hour-long rescue effort. Despite initial concerns about its well-being, Cody emerged unharmed from the ordeal. The incident occurred during the horse's first hurdle, which is notoriously challenging due to its treacherous terrain. After being freed from the mud, Cody was taken back to the stable for further examination by a veterinarian.

Karen Bell, 42, from Hull, was jailed for 12 months for blackmailing a man she met on a dating website, where she threatened to post videos of their intimate moments online unless he paid her £55. The couple met on Plenty of Fish and started a romantic relationship, engaging in sex trysts online. After meeting in person, Bell began blackmailing the man, threatening to share compromising footage unless he paid her money. She eventually obtained £55 from him, but was caught and sentenced to 12 months in prison for blackmailing.

Chelsea forward Didier Drogba has won the Barclays Spirit of the Game award after inspiring charity work in Africa, particularly through his "Didier Drogba Foundation" which aims to provide educational and healthcare support to underprivileged children. The foundation supports initiatives such as providing school bags and medical clinics in his home country of Ivory Coast. Drogba, who has spoken publicly about his humble beginnings playing football in the streets with limited resources, hopes to inspire the next generation of footballers to pursue their passion for the sport. The award comes after a successful campaign raising £400,000 for the foundation, which will fund further development projects.

A senior Islamist party official, Mohammad Qamaruzzaman, was convicted of crimes against humanity and executed in Bangladesh. He was hanged around 10.30pm on Saturday inside Dhaka's Central Jail. Qamaruzzaman was the assistant secretary general of the Jamaat-e-Islami party, which collaborated with the Pakistani army during the 1971 independence war. The country's Supreme Court rejected his final appeal against the death sentence, leading to widespread protests and condemnation from human rights groups.

In the hit US TV series House of Cards, Francis Underwood, played by Kevin Spacey, seeks to manipulate and control the powerful world of Washington D.C.'s politics. To achieve this goal, he uses his cunning and intelligence to gather information about his enemies and invite them to lunch, often using a private dining room at the Capital Grille. The series explores the cutthroat nature of politics and the lengths to which individuals will go to succeed. In Washington, the city is filled with powerful figures who are willing to do whatever it takes to rise to the top.

A 8-year-old boy named Leo Bernal survived being shot in the head by an intruder while sleeping in his home in Culver City, California. The incident occurred on a Friday evening, five days after the shooting, and left Leo with a partially shaved scalp and 23 staples. The intruder fired four shots into the boy's bedroom, striking the wall and causing terror in the household. Leo's mother described the scene as "nightmarish" and expressed her fear of returning home due to the trauma experienced by her son.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring dozens more. An Afghan lawmaker who was participating in the protests was among those injured. The Taliban has denied being responsible for the attack, but no other organization has taken credit. The incident occurred during a protest in the city of Khost, where hundreds of people gathered to demand changes in the provincial government.
World Happiness Report; sustainable development; and chocolate.

A four-year-old North Carolina toddler, Austin West, drowned in a pool last Saturday while chasing a bumblebee in his backyard. His family set up an online fundraiser to help cover his funeral costs, but found that scammers had beaten them to the punch by setting up fake GoFundMe pages. The fake fundraisers have since been removed, but the family is still struggling financially and needs donations to pay for Austin's funeral expenses. They have launched two new campaigns to raise money, including selling cotton T-shirts with Austin's picture for $15 each.

A family rift within the National Front in France deepened yesterday after its founder Jean-Marie Le Pen announced he would step down from the party due to controversy surrounding his comments about the Holocaust and his granddaughter's potential candidacy. Le Pen's daughter, Marine, responded angrily, stating she would oppose his candidacy and accuse him of "political suicide". The move comes amid growing tensions between Le Pen and his granddaughter Marion Marechal-Le Pen, who is seen as more socially conservative than her aunt. Le Pen has chosen to remain as honorary president of the party despite announcing his retirement.

Andrew Getty, the 47-year-old grandson of J. Paul Getty, died in his home in Los Angeles after being found unresponsive by a female friend. The cause of death appears to be natural, but further investigation is needed. An investigation into the circumstances surrounding his death is ongoing, including the presence of medication at the scene. Andrew Getty's father, Gordon Getty, has filed a restraining order against a woman, which may have led to his decision to take his own life.

Cricket is a popular sport with a global reach, featuring amateur and professional players showcasing their skills in various locations around the world. Stunning photographs capture the excitement of the game, including breathtaking shots of players making incredible catches and moments of triumph. Amateur and professional cricketers alike have been featured in this collection of images, highlighting the diversity of the sport. These photographs were chosen for their exceptional quality and impact, earning them a spot on the short-list for the Wisden-MCC Cricket Photograph of the Year award. The images showcase the beauty and drama of the game, capturing the thrill of victory and heartbreak.

A new Reddit thread asking users to submit the most horrendous baby names they have ever come across has attracted over 18,000 comments in just 24 hours, featuring names like "Orgasm", "Mazen", and "Like". Many of these submissions describe how parents gave birth to babies with unusual or disturbing names, often due to a desire to express themselves creatively or make a statement. Some parents claim that their names were chosen because they sounded unique or stood out from other names, while others simply wanted to go against convention. The thread highlights the darker side of online naming trends, where some individuals seem to prioritize aesthetics over the well-being and happiness of their children.

Millions of people in the UK are expected to suffer from hay fever this summer due to warm weather, with predictions suggesting 20 million people will experience symptoms. A 33% increase in hay fever cases is forecasted by 2030, with 31.8 million expected to be affected by 2030. Warm and dry weather with occasional wet spells will help grass grow, triggering high pollen counts. Global trends suggest that hay fever seasons are becoming longer, with warmer temperatures leading to earlier plant growth and increased pollen production. By Friday, the hottest day of the year, pollen counts are expected to surge, making it essential for sufferers to prepare with antihistamines and other treatments.

Raheem Sterling signed a new deal with Liverpool and announced he will wait until the summer to decide on his future, revealing he has tender years etched onto his forearm. Born in Jamaica, Sterling grew up in a tough environment, overcoming challenges such as gun crime and gang violence, before joining Liverpool's youth academy at 11. His impressive performances earned him a spot in England's senior team, including a record-breaking 14 caps and a 3-2 victory over Norwich in 2014. Sterling's current £35,000-per-week deal has two years remaining, and he is expected to be one of the biggest signings in Liverpool's history.

TV star Karren Brady appeared alongside Prime Minister David Cameron at a National Grid training centre in Newark, Nottinghamshire, to announce the creation of 16,000 new apprenticeships. She helped stand beside him while he spoke about the importance of apprenticeships for young people's futures. Despite her initial hopes of stealing the spotlight, Brady opted to sit quietly by his side. This move was seen as a nod to the government's efforts to promote apprenticeships, which aim to provide young people with valuable skills and employment opportunities.

A daredevil adventurer, Oscar Hübinette, attempted to ski down the slopes of the Tolbachik volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia after its recent eruption. The volcano, which had lain dormant since 1976, erupted in November 2012, spewing lava up to 656 feet high. The photographer, Fredrik Schenholm, captured stunning images of the volcano's fiery landscape, including Oscar skiing down the icy slopes amidst the lava flows. This was Schenholm's fifth attempt to photograph active volcanoes, and he described the experience as "incredible" and "unreal".

Newcastle manager John Carver has vowed to motivate his players ahead of the upcoming Tyne-Wear derby against Sunderland, saying he will "whip" them to ensure they win. The Magpies have struggled in recent matches against their North-East rivals, losing four consecutive games, and Carver believes this is a crucial opportunity for them to turn things around. With Sunderland seeking revenge after being out-worked in their last four meetings, Carver wants his players to rise to the challenge. Newcastle will look to end their run of defeats and maintain their mid-table position, while Sunderland aim to keep their Premier League status intact. The Magpies will be led by French midfielder Moussa Sissoko, who has impressed in his role under Carver.

Rangers goalkeeper Steve Simonsen, 35, has been unsuccessful in having his one-game ban for breaching Scottish Football Association (SFA) betting laws increased. The SFA appealed the decision, but it was upheld by an appellate tribunal. Simonsen admitted to betting on 50 games in a year, despite serving a one-match ban. His legal team argued that the punishment was too lenient, citing previous cases where players received harsher penalties for similar offenses.

A former England player, Bobby Moore, famously hugged Brazilian legend Pele after scoring a goal in a 1-0 win for England in the 1970 World Cup final. This moment of sportsmanship has been widely emulated, but now seems to be fading away due to the increasing intensity of the modern game. A recent incident involving Newcastle keeper Tim Krul and Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe has sparked criticism, with some accusing Krul of being "inappropriate" and lacking sportsmanship. However, others argue that the gesture was simply a genuine expression of admiration for Defoe's skillful goal-scoring performance.

The Obamas paid over $93,000 in federal taxes on an income of over $477,000, with an effective tax rate of 19.6%. They claimed nearly $160,000 in itemized deductions, including $70,712 in charitable donations, totaling 15% of their income. The couple also made $395,000 in wages and sold their bestselling books for $116,000, resulting in a total book revenue of $21,000. In contrast, the Bidens paid $90,000 in federal taxes on an income of nearly $389,000, with an effective tax rate of 23.3%, and reported $7,380 in charitable donations.

Marcelo Bosch has signed a contract extension with Saracens, extending his time at the club until the end of the 2024 season. He played a key role in their European Champions Cup quarter-final victory over Racing Metro just 11 days prior. Bosch joins fellow forwards George Kruis and Maro Itoje on new deals. This move comes after Bosch had already been with the team since 2013. The signing is seen as a boost to Saracens' hopes of competing in the Champions Cup semi-finals.

Amal Clooney, the wife of George Clooney, held a press conference in Washington DC, calling for the release of former Maldivian President Mohamed Nasheed, who was convicted under tough anti-terror laws and sentenced to 13 years in prison. Clooney, a high-powered human rights lawyer, appeared alongside her husband and wife Laila Ali and Jared Genser, and expressed her determination to see Nasheed released. The case against Nasheed stems from allegations of wrongful detention by the Maldivian military, and Amnesty International has condemned the "sham trial" as a "travesty of justice". Clooney vowed to continue fighting for Nasheed's freedom until he is released.

41-year-old mother-of-two has spoken about her journey to becoming a mother and balancing her career and family life. 'I've learned that it's okay to ask for help and that it's okay to prioritize your health', she said. Paula's story is one of determination and perseverance and her legacy continues to inspire millions around the world.

Arsenal midfielder Aaron Ramsey scored 25 goals for the club since the start of last season, including a dramatic extra-time winner in the FA Cup final against Burnley. The victory marked a significant milestone for Ramsey, who dedicated the goal to his late grandmother, Eileen, who passed away recently. The win was a relief for Ramsey, who had been on an emotional rollercoaster of late due to personal losses. He praised his family and teammates for their support, saying they were "on my mum's side" and that he felt proud to have achieved his dreams. With the win, Arsenal moved into the FA Cup semi-finals, where they face Reading in a highly anticipated encounter.

A teenager in the UK pranked her mother by pretending to be kidnapped, using a fake phone call and threatening demands for money to get her child back. The prank went viral online, receiving over 20,000 retweets and 30,000 favorites. Despite being caught out, the teenager convinced her mother that the situation was real, even going so far as to send a picture of herself perched on the sofa. In the end, the mother was left furious and humiliated, while the teenager received widespread praise for her creativity and humor.

Thousands of migrants and refugees have arrived in Sicily, Italy, since last weekend, with over 10,000 people having landed on the island since January 1st. The influx is part of a long-standing trend of migrants seeking refuge in Italy due to conflict and persecution in North Africa. The Italian authorities have struggled to cope with the surge, with many migrants being left without access to basic services such as healthcare and housing. Despite efforts to process asylum claims, many migrants are forced to flee to neighboring countries, exacerbating the humanitarian crisis.

West Ham manager Sam Allardyce defended his team despite criticism from co-owner David Sullivan, who felt they had been "exceedingly disappointing" in the Barclays Premier League since the start of the season. Allardyce argued that the team's performance should be judged based on overall results rather than individual performances. He cited the team's recent wins over last year's total by two points as evidence of their success. Sullivan had previously expressed disappointment with the team's form, but Allardyce countered that the team's overall record was still impressive.

During the upcoming school exam season, parents and students alike may feel nervous and anxious about performing well. A new survey by Lancashire's Edge Hill University and the University of South Australia has found a direct link between anxiety and poor exam performance, suggesting that worrying about grades can negatively impact results. To alleviate stress, parents can encourage their children to create a revision plan, use revision aids like flashcards and practice questions, and stay focused on their goals. By doing so, students can improve their chances of success and develop a growth mindset.

Scotland's European Challenge Cup hopes have been dealt a significant blow after centre Matt Scott underwent an operation on his left shoulder, ruling him out until at least the end of the season. This comes after he suffered another injury in Scotland's recent Six Nations match against Ireland. The injury is a second operation for Scott, who has struggled with shoulder issues throughout his career. With Scotland facing a tough challenge without Scott, the team will need to find alternative options at centre, particularly in September's World Cup. The loss of Scott and potentially others like him will impact Edinburgh's chances of making it to the final.

Bobby Flay's marriage to actress Stephanie March has reportedly ended due to allegations of infidelity, with his assistant Elyse Tirrell allegedly having an affair with him for three years. The two were married for 10 years before filing for divorce, with Flay claiming that the marriage "irretrievably broke down" due to the affair. However, Tirrell's friend Maia Madison claims that March found out about the affair just after Thanksgiving 2014 and is seeking to use it as leverage to get out of paying Flay $5,000 per month in alimony. Flay's business partner Laurence Kretchmer denies the allegations, stating that Tirrell is a valued employee and that any claim of infidelity would have been reported to him.

Ann Summers, a lingerie and toy retailer, has released its first bridal wear collection, featuring a range of intimate apparel designed specifically for brides-to-be. The collection includes items such as curve-skimming dresses, nightgowns, and silk and lace sets, all priced between £14 and £85. The lingerie line is marketed as "perfect for every blushing bride" and features a mix of soft palettes of ivory and nude, along with some more daring pieces like a bra with a cut-out design. The collection is available in sizes 8-12 and 32A-38DD, making it suitable for brides who want to add a touch of romance to their wedding attire.

The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) removed the name "Isis" from its list of future Pacific hurricane names due to its association with the militant group ISIS, which is responsible for brutal atrocities against civilians. The decision comes after the WMO Hurricane Committee deemed the name inappropriate due to its connection to the terrorist organization. The WMO has a rotating list of storm names that alternates between male and female names, and Isis was previously listed in 2016. The removal of the name marks the first time a name has been removed from the list since 2007.

A leak of Game of Thrones' first four episodes has occurred, with nearly half of the season being shared online. The leaks came from a group approved by HBO to receive the content, and include popular characters like Jon Snow and Tyrion Lannister. The episodes began appearing on torrent download sites on Saturday night, causing frustration among fans who wanted to avoid spoilers. The leak is part of a larger trend of international piracy of the show, which has seen significant growth since its release in 2011.

A recent poll shows that more than half of voters do not want Nicola Sturgeon or the Scottish National Party (SNP) to play a key role in the next British government, with 54% opposing the idea. A ComRes poll found that 59% of voters want the SNP to play no part in running the country, while 36% support the idea of the Lib Dems joining forces with Labour. The SNP's demands for increased spending, an end to benefits cuts, and the scrapping of Trident have been met with widespread opposition, particularly among older voters. The poll also suggests that the Conservative Party, led by David Cameron, may be seen as a more attractive option due to its perceived ability to avoid a hung parliament.

Olivia Phillips, a journalist, took to the streets of Dubai dressed as Barbie doll Jeremy Scott's spring/summer 2015 collection for Moschino, showcasing the iconic designer's latest trend. She navigated the city's supermarkets and streets, where she received overwhelming reactions from passersby, with many smiling and greeting her. Her bold outfit included a spray-on leather skirt suit, a biker jacket, and a high-heeled shoe, which seemed to bring out the playful side of the fashion world. Despite initial skepticism, Olivia found that her unique look garnered attention and admiration from strangers, cementing her status as a style icon.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade through the streets around Stamford Bridge to celebrate their potential Premier League title win, if they secure it. The parade will take place on May 25 if Chelsea win the league, with a route starting near the stadium and ending at Eel Brook Common. If they don't win, the parade will not occur. The event will be funded by the club itself, with buses departing from Stamford Bridge's west entrance and traveling east along Fulham Road. Chelsea are currently nine points clear of second-placed Manchester City at the top of the table.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, the son of influential San Diego businessman Glenn Doshay, was arrested last week for allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from a local elementary school. The incident occurred on March 23, and Doshay was arrested nine days later after a resident reported the crime to the authorities. Doshay is currently being held without bail at a residential facility while facing charges of kidnapping, false imprisonment with violence, and child cruelty. A parent of the victim described him as "the wrong guy" and praised the girl's bravery for speaking out against him.
