Kumar Sangakkara, the 37-year-old Sri Lankan cricketer, has been asked by Sports Minister Navin Dissanayake to reconsider retiring from limited overs cricket due to his disappointing performance in the World Cup quarter-final loss. Sangakkara had previously expressed disappointment with his own performance but may be swayed by the opportunity to continue playing Test cricket. Sangakkara has already played 14,234 one-day matches and holds the record for most dismissals by a wicketkeeper. To address his concerns, Sangakkara will continue to play for English county side Surrey this season.

Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has called for the retirement age to be frozen at its current level of 66, citing that it is unfair to Scottish pensioners due to their shorter lifespan compared to other parts of the UK. The SNP demands a significant increase in the state pension, currently set at £113 per week, to £160 per week, while also calling for an end to austerity measures and the scrapping of the Trident nuclear missile system. This move would come despite the potential financial costs, estimated to be over £12.5 billion. The SNP's stance is seen as a response to the growing concern about the impact of rising life expectancy on pensioners' living standards.

A Kentucky judge, Olu Stevens, faced criticism for criticizing a couple's victim impact statements during a sentencing hearing, accusing them of fostering racist stereotypes in their 3-year-old daughter. The couple, Gregory and Jordan Gray, testified that their daughter was traumatized by the experience and expressed fear of black men due to a written statement prepared by her mother. The statement claimed that the child was "in constant fear of black men" and had become fearful of black males since the crime. The judge's comments sparked outrage, with many calling for him to be sacked. The couple's lawyer argued that the statement was not intended to be racist and that the judge's remarks were unjustified.

A series of mysterious cardboard signs have appeared in a Surrey village, sparking speculation about the identity of the person responsible. The signs feature messages such as "I love you" and "we need to talk", which some believe may be attempts to apologize for an argument between two lovers. Many people use traditional methods to express remorse, but these signs suggest a more creative approach. Despite being seen in other parts of the country, the identity of the person behind the signs remains unknown.

Five Chinese feminist activists, aged 20-30, have been detained by police for over a month for "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" while handing out leaflets about sexual harassment on public transport. The women, including Li Tingting, 25, have been accused of "provoking trouble" and are facing up to five-year prison terms if convicted. The activists, who have been vocal advocates for women's rights and better access to public restrooms, were detained on International Women's Day and have been denied bail. The US government has condemned the detention, with President Joe Biden calling for their release and Secretary of State John Kerry backing their cause.

A formal ceremony begins to honor the diggers who fought and fell in the Gallipoli landings, with over 10,000 Australians and New Zealanders gathered on the shores of the Gallipoli peninsula to pay their respects. The ceremony marks the 100th anniversary of the bloody landings, which saw 130,000 men die, including 87,000 Ottomans, 8700 Australians, 2779 New Zealanders, and 21,000 British soldiers. The event features a massive sea of pilgrims, with dignitaries including Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott, New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, and Prince Charles and Prince Harry in attendance. The ceremony honors the bravery and sacrifice of the diggers who fought and fell in the war, and serves as a reminder of the importance of remembrance and unity among nations.

Atletico Madrid suffered a 2-2 draw against Malaga, with Fernando Torres scoring his first league goal for the club. Torres headed a corner kick to equalize the score just before halftime, and then scored again in the second half. Malaga goalkeeper Carlos Kameni made several crucial saves to deny Atletico their lead. Despite struggling to create clear-cut chances, Malaga's defense held firm until Antoine Griezmann scored twice to secure a point for Diego Simeone's side. Torres had previously struggled to find form since returning to Atletico Madrid in January.

Danny Lennon, the former St Mirren manager, has been appointed as the new interim coach of the Scotland Under 21 football team. His tenure came to an end when he was officially replaced by Paddy Connolly, who took over temporarily. Lennon had previously taken charge of the team for a 2-1 victory against Hungary in March. He will remain in the role until the summer of 2016, when a permanent appointment will be made.

A battered and rusted bus and train, lying abandoned in the Great Smokey Mountains in North Carolina, were used to film a memorable action scene from the 1993 film "The Fugitive". The scene, which involved Harrison Ford's character escaping from a prison transport, was filmed using a real train crashing into a real bus, resulting in significant damage and leaving the vehicles covered in overgrown weeds. The wreckage has remained on location for 23 years, becoming a popular tourist attraction. Fans of the film will recognize the bus and train due to their appearance in the iconic scene.

A 28-year-old man, Bradley James Brooks, was charged with murder after stabbing a 28-year-old rugby player, Greg Gibbins, outside a pizza shop in the early hours of Easter Monday. The incident occurred while Gibbins was helping a woman being harassed, and police believe it was unrelated to an earlier incident involving a woman. Brooks was arrested and charged with murder after allegedly attacking Gibbins with a knife, leaving him dead in hospital. An investigation is ongoing, and police are reviewing CCTV footage from the hotel where the incident took place. Brooks will appear in court next month.

A Reddit thread has gained over 10,000 comments discussing the experiences of men who have purchased mail-order brides from Russia and the Philippines. Many men reported being surprised by how similar their wives spoke to their own language skills, with some describing the experience as awkward or uncomfortable. Some men hired translators to facilitate communication, while others noted that the lack of emotional connection was a major issue. Despite the initial excitement, many men eventually realized that their wives were not interested in a traditional relationship and ended up meeting new people and forming friendships.

Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart expressed disappointment and frustration after his team's 4-2 defeat to Manchester United, describing it as one of his "worst days" in a Manchester City jersey. He felt that the team's performance was marred by a series of errors, including goals conceded by Ashley Young, Marouane Fellaini, Juan Mata, and Chris Smalling. Hart acknowledged that the defeat has left him feeling "devastated", especially considering the team's bid to retain their Premier League title. The loss has also derailed Manchester City's hopes of finishing third, putting them four points behind their arch-rivals Manchester United. Hart reflected on the game, saying that it was an "unfortunate" result and vowed to bounce back stronger next week.

A Northern Territory mother, Noeleen Foster, captured a phallic-shaped cloud while working at a construction site in Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin. She was taken aback by the unusual shape and described it as "suspiciously suggestive". The image was shared on social media, sparking widespread interest and amusement. This is not the first time a naturally occurring phallic cloud has been photographed, with similar images also appearing in England and Wales.

A Boston Terrier named Gizmo learned to perform a gravity-defying trick by wearing new black booties, which allowed him to take several steps forward before landing on all fours. The footage shows Gizmo successfully executing the move, with his owner Loren Mathieson cheering him on. The trick has been viewed over 80,000 times since its release. Gizmo's impressive feat showcases his agility and coordination. Mathieson credits the booties for helping him master the skill.

Porto, the only undefeated side in the Champions League, face off against Bayern Munich in their quarter-final first leg, with Julen Lopetegui warning that his team "hasn't stopped growing" despite not having much to prove. The Portuguese side has had a remarkable run, winning all four of their Champions League matches so far, and Lopetegui aims to continue this momentum. Bayern Munich, meanwhile, are looking to overcome their recent losses, particularly against Shakhtar Donetsk, which they defeated 7-0. Lopetegui sees no reason for Bayern to change their approach, citing their ability to stop opponents from scoring. With a strong defense and improved team chemistry, Porto should be confident of advancing to the semi-finals.

Schoolboy Frankie Franz, 9, from Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club, scored an audacious 27-yard goal in a basketball hoop using a trick shot emulated by Barcelona star Martin Montoya. Frankie watched Montoya perform the move during a video recording session at Barcelona's Ciutat Esportiva training ground. The youngster then attempted the feat himself, successfully sending the ball through the net twice before being mobbed by his teammates. Frankie's parents, Lucy and Matt, were amazed by their son's skills and confidence.

Maksims Uvarenko, a financially-strained Latvian goalkeeper for CSKA Sofia, has asked his parents to send him money to cover his rent due to unpaid salaries. Despite being a member of the club for only three months, Uvarenko has expressed gratitude towards the "unique" fans and their support. CSKA Sofia is facing financial difficulties, having recently sold the club to billionaire Vasil Bozhkov nine years ago, which led to a decline in revenue and debt. The team has struggled to settle debts to various parties, including the National Social Security Institute and National Revenue Agency. Uvarenko hopes that fans will help alleviate his financial woes.

Parma beat Juventus 1-0 in a surprising result, thanks to a late goal from Ishak Belfodil. This was Parma's second win of the season, following a 1-1 draw against Inter Milan. The win moved them up to 10th place, while Juventus remain in last place with 9 points from safety. Meanwhile, Genoa beat Cagliari 2-0, ending a seven-match winless streak in Serie A. Inter Milan ended a seven-match winless run in all competitions with a 3-0 win over Verona.

Simon Brann Thorpe's documentary-style photograph series "Toy Soldiers" documents the lives of soldiers in Western Sahara, using green plastic figurines as props to convey the harsh reality of war and conflict. The project aims to spark a deeper emotional and political response by presenting the same images on social media platforms, bypassing traditional media outlets. By placing soldiers in a desolate desert landscape, Thorpe creates a powerful metaphor for viewers to connect with the human cost of war. Through his photographs, Thorpe seeks to raise awareness about the plight of the people affected by the ongoing conflict.

A 7-year-old boy was raped and set on fire by two youths while buying food in a secluded area in Mumbai's Pagma Nagar neighborhood. The incident involved attempted rape and assault, with the perpetrators setting the boy on fire after resisting. The boy escaped with severe burns but is currently receiving treatment at a nearby hospital. An investigation is underway, with charges of attempt to murder, sodomy, and child sexual offenses being filed against the suspects. The incident is being investigated by the police in collaboration with other authorities.

Jurgen Klopp, the manager of Borussia Dortmund, has confirmed that he will leave the club at the end of the current season after seven years in charge. He was immediately installed as the bookmakers' favourite to replace Manuel Pellegrini at Manchester City, despite being considered a strong candidate for the role. Klopp has expressed his desire to find a new challenge and believes that Dortmund need a change of manager. He will officially cease to be Dortmund manager on June 30 and has left the club for good. This marks the end of a successful seven-year tenure at the helm of the Westfalenstadion.

Sean McCabe, a father of three, was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin lymphoma at age 28 and underwent intensive chemotherapy, only to have it return in an aggressive form two months later. Despite the setback, he made a remarkable recovery and was told he was in remission. Two years later, he planned his own funeral and chose to get married to his fiancée Lisa Williams, who was also his partner for 12 years. His children were involved in the planning process, and he wrote a heartfelt letter to each of them, expressing his love and gratitude.

A 8-year-old boy and his 13-year-old brother died after their car crashed into the Los Angeles harbor, with their father pulling them from the water. The incident occurred when the car veered off the edge of the harbor and into the water, resulting in both children's deaths. A firefighter who dove into the water to rescue them was hailed as a hero. The cause of the accident remains unknown, and nearly 100 emergency responders attended the scene.

Qatar's investment arm, Qatar Holding, has acquired a majority stake in the company behind the iconic Claridge's hotel in London. This move tightens its grip on the city's real estate market. The acquisition comes after Constellation Hotels, a subsidiary of Qatar's Constellation Hotels, purchased a 64% stake in the hotel company Coroin, which owns several five-star hotels, including Claridge's, The Berkeley, and The Connaught. This latest acquisition is part of Qatar's efforts to expand its presence in London and strengthen its position in the global real estate market.

A 35-year-old woman, Akon Guode, was released from custody after being interviewed by police regarding the deaths of three children in a car crash near Melbourne. The children, aged one, two, and four, drowned in a lake after their 4WD plunged into the water. Guode was questioned as part of the ongoing investigation into the incident. The mother, who fled Sudan to escape war, was described as "a good mother" by her cousin, who said she loved the children. An investigation is ongoing, and police are seeking information from anyone who may have seen the car involved in the crash.

Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed an algorithm that analyzes keystroke patterns to detect Parkinson's disease, potentially revolutionizing the fight against the debilitating neurodegenerative disorder. By analyzing the timing and duration of keystrokes, the algorithm can identify individuals who are more likely to have Parkinson's disease, allowing for early detection and intervention. This breakthrough technology has the potential to save lives and improve treatment outcomes. Overall, the discovery offers hope for a new approach to diagnosing and managing Parkinson's disease.

Raheem Sterling, 20, has expressed his commitment to staying at Liverpool despite being offered a £100,000-a-week contract to join Arsenal. The young England star has stated that he is "flattered" by the offer, but insists he is not ready to sign a new contract at Anfield. Sterling has also revealed that he dreams of playing abroad and has mentioned that he used to play for goalposts on streets and in parks as a child. The 20-year-old has admitted that he is "tender years" and is focused solely on developing his football skills at Liverpool.

Stoke City manager Mark Hughes has dismissed rumors linking Asmir Begovic with a transfer to Real Madrid, saying "there will be a lot of stories bandied about" but he doesn't believe them. The Bosnian goalkeeper is out of contract in 2016 and Hughes hopes he stays with the Potters. Stoke are working on signing Moha El Ouriachi from Barcelona, who is set to join from the Catalan club. The 19-year-old winger is considered one of the top young players in the world and Hughes believes he can help improve the Potters' youth team. Stoke will be without several key players, including Marc Muniesa and Victor Moses, but Hughes remains optimistic about their chances of making the playoffs.

clashed in a chaotic finale. In the 90th minute, a wild tackle by Mason on Weimann resulted in a red card for the Villa captain. The final whistle blew and the players celebrated with joyous abandon. It was a fitting end to what was a rollercoaster of emotions for Villa fans.

Gerard "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a notorious mob enforcer from Rhode Island, died in a North Carolina prison at age 75 due to lung cancer. Ouimette was a key figure in the infamous La Cosa Nostra organization, controlling a vast network of crimes including extortion, loansharking, and murder. He spent over 46 years behind bars, including time in a maximum-security prison in Rhode Island, where he was known to have smuggled food and liquor to inmates, including a young boy, and even hosted lavish parties. Ouimette was convicted of multiple crimes, including extortion and murder, and became the first person in New England to receive life in prison under the federal three-strikes law.

Danny Cipriani has taken advantage of a rare free weekend after helping Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester last Saturday. He contributed 13 points from the boot in the match, which helped the team stay out of contention in Europe. With the playoffs still a possibility, Cipriani has chosen to spend his time relaxing in Dubai instead. This break comes ahead of Sale's upcoming Aviva Premiership fixtures, where they will face London Irish, Harlequins, Newcastle, and Exeter. Cipriani's return to action is expected to be on April 12, when he will face London Irish at the Madejski Stadium.

Owen Farrell is expected to return to form for Saracens after missing the RBS 6 Nations due to a knee ligament injury sustained during their match against Clermont in January. He hopes to be ready for the European Champions Cup semi-final against Clermont on April 18. Farrell has been working hard in training and is optimistic about his chances of returning to the field. His return will come just ahead of Saracens' next Premiership match against Leicester. Farrell's injury has left him without a significant impact on the team so far this season.

Officer Michael Slager, 33, is being held in isolation due to his alleged role in the murder of Walter Scott, 50, after opening fire on him while stopped for a broken tail light in North Charleston, South Carolina. Slager is housed in a small room with limited interaction with other inmates and has been cleared to move to general population once the cell blocks are cleared. A video shows Slager meeting Scott, who was attempting to flee after being pulled over, and the two engage in a brief conversation before Scott flees. An investigation reveals that Slager had a history of financial issues, including owing thousands of dollars in child support, and may have been motivated by a desire to avoid returning to jail.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino believes goalkeeper Michel Vorm can help replace injured star goalkeeper Hugo Lloris in the Capital One Cup final against Burnley. Vorm, who replaced Lloris in the previous round, will start alongside Lloris in Turf Moor after Lloris suffered a knee injury. Pochettino praises Vorm's mental toughness and ability to perform under pressure, having previously left Lloris' position at Swansea. Despite being behind Lloris in the pecking order, Vorm has shown consistency in playing regularly for Tottenham. Pochettino hopes Vorm can provide stability and leadership as Tottenham look to bounce back from a disappointing loss in the Premier League.

A woman in New York City was shocked to receive a $16,000 bill from an Uber ride despite being only 35 minutes late for a fundraiser event. The driver allegedly took a detour through multiple lanes and ignored the GPS, causing the woman to feel unsafe throughout the trip. An Uber spokesperson apologized for the mistake but claimed the driver was not responsible for the error, stating it was a "clerical" issue. However, the woman disputed the claim, saying she was never charged the high amount and was eventually refunded $15 after contacting the company.

A large cloud formation resembling the Wi-Fi symbol appeared in central China, giving locals their "world's largest" WiFi signal. This natural phenomenon occurred when Mother Nature lent a helping hand, providing internet access to those without coverage. Students at Hunan University captured the moment on camera, and Chinese internet users quickly shared photos and jokes about the unexpected gift. The cloud formation was reminiscent of the global Wi-Fi symbol, sparking amusement and curiosity among residents.

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere met Brazilian legend Pele at a launch party for 10Ten Talent, where he was interviewed by Pele himself. The event was attended by Pele, Glenn Hoddle, and other 10Ten Talent clients, including Oscar and Ramires. Pele expressed his disappointment with Brazil's performance at the World Cup, saying it was "something nobody can explain" after scoring 77 goals in 92 games for his country. Despite the disappointment, Pele praised the players who have bounced back in the Premier League, including Oscar and Ramires.

In Italy, a growing number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are attempting to cross the Mediterranean Sea in search of a better life, with over 8,480 reported rescued between Friday and Monday. Many of these migrants are desperate and hope to reach Europe, but the journey is fraught with danger due to overcrowding and poor conditions on board. The Italian coast guard has reported a significant surge in migrant arrivals, with many using Libya as a transiting point. Despite efforts to rescue those in distress, there have been reports of migrants dying or going missing at sea.

Jacques Burger of Saracens has been cited for alleged foul play during their European Champions Cup quarter-final match against Racing Metro. The incident occurred midway through the game and resulted in a two-week ban for the flanker. A disciplinary hearing is scheduled for Thursday, with a possible penalty for the offense. Burger faces a significant punishment, ranging from eight weeks to 52 weeks, depending on the severity of the infraction. This decision comes after a dramatic win for Saracens over Racing Metro.

A volcanic eruption occurred at Chile's Calbuco Volcano, prompting evacuations and ash fall in the surrounding areas. The third eruption since last week has been described as spectacular but less intense than previous events, with ash production reduced compared to the April 22 and April 23 eruptions. Over 1,500 people were evacuated, with a 20-kilometer exclusion zone established around the crater. The region has seen significant ash fall, with homes and buildings affected by the volcanic debris, and authorities have issued warnings for potential ash-related health risks.

Six people, including five men and one woman, have been arrested in connection with suspected Syria-related terrorism offences in the UK. The arrests took place in the south coast port area of Dover, where searches are ongoing. The individuals are believed to be from Birmingham, West Midlands, and are not considered to pose an immediate threat to public safety. One of the arrested individuals is the son of a local politician, Waheed Ahmed, who was detained in Turkey for attempting to enter Syria.

Philadelphia beat New York City FC 2-1 in their first Major League Soccer victory of the season, thanks to a stoppage-time goal by Vincent Nogueira. The game ended in a 6-yard box defending a cross, with Nogueira toe-poking it home in the 92nd minute. New York City goalkeeper Josh Saunders collided with Conor Casey inside the 6-yard box, allowing Nogueira to score. The Union's first Major League Soccer victory came on Saturday, marking a significant milestone in the season. The game also featured a notable collision between Saunders and Casey, which led to Nogueira's winning goal.

A British church preacher, Eric Isaiah Adusah, 41, is being held on suspicion of murdering his pregnant wife, Charmain Adusah, 41, in a hotel room in Ghana. The body of Charmain was discovered by hotel staff face down in a bath, believed to be lying for four days. The couple had traveled to Ghana together, with Charmain's husband returning to the UK after attending a three-day church event in Ghana. Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding Charmain's death, with suspicion of murder hanging over the situation.

A former aide to Jeb Bush, Ethan Czahor, has launched an app called 'Clear' that removes any posts that might cause problems with your current or future employers. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze tweets and determine whether they are offensive or not, giving users a safety rating between 0 and 100. The app aims to prevent employees from being fired due to past tweets, and is currently available for registration on the iOS store. Users can choose to "let" or "not let" certain tweets remain on their profile, allowing them to control what information is visible to others.

Justin Rose, the current leader in the Masters, finished second after a strong showing in the tournament, marking a successful start to his season. He believes his recent improvement can carry over into bigger events, particularly those in April and September. Rose credits his improved form to kicking off the season strongly, hoping to build on his momentum. His second-place finish at the Masters was a significant step forward, and he aims to continue playing well in upcoming tournaments. With Rory McIlroy's success in the past, Rose sees an opportunity to follow suit and potentially claim more victories.

A college student at a Texas-based country music festival, identified only by her anonymity, managed to avoid getting caught for underage drinking by beating three police officers playing a game of Rock Paper Scissors. The incident occurred during an event called Chilifest, where attendees were allowed to drink beer and wine. The student's victory was captured on video, which quickly spread online and garnered widespread attention. The officers involved were later revealed to be from the College Station Police Department, although their identities remain unknown. The incident sparked a mix of amusement and outrage among viewers, with some expressing surprise at the leniency shown to the student.

A 14-year-old girl named Sally Gordon-Smith went missing near Melbourne after being last seen leaving her school in Keilor East at 3pm on Friday. Police are desperately searching for her and are concerned about her safety due to her age. The girl was described as Caucasian, 150cm tall, with blue eyes and brown hair, and was wearing blue jeans, a black jumper, and black shoes when she disappeared. Police urge anyone who may have seen her to come forward and report their sighting.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew has denied rumors of a potential transfer bid for Newcastle goalkeeper Tim Krul, stating there's been "no contact" between him and the Magpies. Pardew has expressed confidence in his current goalkeeper, Julian Speroni, and believes they can find another solution for the future without making a move for Krul. He also ruled out the possibility of signing a new goalkeeper from outside the Premier League. Pardew wants to focus on building a strong squad rather than rushing into a transfer window.

British photographer John Daniels has taken stunning photographs of adorable puppies posing for the camera, showcasing their personalities and quirks through various settings and props. Using a combination of studio backgrounds and comedy props, Daniels captures heartwarming moments between the animals and their handlers. His approach involves gentle handling, careful timing, and creative uses of sounds to engage the animals, resulting in unique and endearing images. With years of experience working with animals, Daniels finds that outdoor shoots can be challenging due to the risk of escape or fright, making the studio setting ideal for capturing the perfect shot.

Hilary Border, 54, a 54-year-old woman from Newark, Nottinghamshire, stole £20,000 from her dementia-stricken mother, Dorothy, who suffers from various health issues, including angina, sclerosis of the liver, and low blood pressure. Despite being given power of attorney to manage her mother's finances, Border allegedly spent the money on herself instead of paying the required care home fees. She was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, after pleading guilty to fraud. Border's actions were described as "wicked" by the judge, who emphasized the severity of the crime and the harm caused to her mother.

David Suchet, a 68-year-old actor best known for his role as Hercule Poirot, is a proud grandfather to his 1-year-old grandson who has Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, a rare genetic disease that affects the development of organs such as the brain and heart. Despite being diagnosed at birth, Suchet's grandson faces a challenging future due to the lack of effective treatment options. To raise awareness and funds for the condition, Suchet has launched a social media campaign using the hashtag #Fight4Treatment. With his characteristic charm and wit, Suchet is urging others to join him in advocating for better care for those affected by this incurable disease.

Cheteshwar Pujara has joined Yorkshire until the end of May after signing a new contract with the county. He will join from India and will spend time with Derbyshire before potentially linking up with the England national team. Pujara, 27, is expected to make his international debut for England and is seen as a key player in India's Test squad. The move comes after Younis Khan's departure from Yorkshire, and Pujara expressed his desire to play for the county again.

A heroic Belgian Malinois dog named Layka, who lost her entire front leg while clearing a Taliban compound in Afghanistan, has been welcomed into the home of US Army Staff Sgt Julian McDonald in Columbus, Ohio. Despite being injured, Layka completed the mission and underwent emergency surgery, but was later left without a leg due to the cost of treatment. However, Sgt. McDonald decided to bring her home to live with his family, citing his responsibility to care for her. Layka has since formed a strong bond with Sgt. McDonald's children, and even becomes fast friends with his son Liam. She now resides with the family, where she remains a cherished companion.

New research questions conventional wisdom on salt consumption, suggesting that excessive salt intake may not pose significant health risks. The Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee recommends limiting daily salt intake to 2,300 milligrams, but a recent study found that this amount may not be enough to prevent cardiovascular disease. Experts disagree on whether too little salt or too much salt poses greater health risks. Some argue that moderate salt consumption is safe for most people, while others claim that even small amounts can cause harm. The controversy highlights the ongoing debate over the optimal level of salt intake and the need for further research.

US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) agents in Colombia allegedly participated in sex parties with prostitutes from 2001 onwards, according to a new report. The report, which was released by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, claims that several DEA agents attended these parties, despite being warned about the potential risks. The incident has sparked outrage, particularly given previous reports of similar allegations against other federal agencies, including the Secret Service. The DEA has denied any wrongdoing, citing a lack of evidence, but the report suggests that the agency may have been aware of the parties' existence. The allegations have led to calls for greater accountability and oversight within the agency.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy, Burt Hazeltine, was ambushed and shot three times while directing traffic near a school zone in Paradis, Louisiana, sparking a road rage incident. The suspect, 56-year-old Paul Devillier, opened fire on Hazeltine, who was directing traffic in a school zone, and was also injured. Hazeltine is in stable condition at Interim LSU Hospital, although he may lose his sight due to a bullet wound to his eye. Devillier had a history of mental health issues and was fired from his job at the Transportation Safety Administration in 2013.

Lord Janner, a 86-year-old Labour peer, signed a letter stating he wanted to remain in the House of Lords despite being deemed unfit to face child sex charges due to Alzheimer's disease. Campaigners questioned why he was allowed to remain in the House of Lords if he was too frail to be brought before court. The Crown Prosecution Service announced that Janner would escape prosecution due to his dementia, sparking controversy and anger from abuse campaigners. Critics argue that Janner's ability to sign the letter raises questions about his fitness to stand trial, given his deteriorating health.

Turkey has blocked access to Twitter and YouTube due to a request from a Turkish court to remove images of a prosecutor held during an armed siege, citing concerns about the spread of "terrorist propaganda". The images show the prosecutor, Mehmet Selim Kiraz, being held hostage by the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), a far-left organization considered a terrorist group by Turkey, the EU, and the US. The prosecutor died in hospital after being shot during the standoff, and his wife and two children are grieving. The US has condemned the Turkish government's actions, while Turkey's telecoms regulator says it cannot immediately unblock the sites due to a court order.

David and Victoria Beckham have won a planning battle to install air conditioning at their £31.5 million mansion in west London, despite neighbor's concerns about its impact on the historic character of the Victorian house. The couple's new home, which includes a luxury gym, wine cellar, and large wine storage space, will feature six bedrooms, a study, office, and playroom. The plans were approved by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council after neighbors expressed "deep concerns" about noise, vibration, and pollution from the construction. The Beckhams' restoration project aims to preserve the property's historic character and value, with estimates suggesting it could increase the property's value to up to £42 million upon completion.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25% overall cutback in water use across the state, impacting cities and towns, as well as private property owners, due to the ongoing drought. This move aims to conserve water resources, despite the fact that California has a surplus of water reserves and record-low snowfall this winter. The cutback targets areas such as golf courses, cemeteries, and businesses, while exempting agriculture, which accounts for 80% of the state's water consumption. The goal is to encourage water conservation and reduce waste, but critics argue that the plan may not be effective, given the state's history of drought and the reluctance of some homeowners to change their habits.

CNN reports that Universal's "Furious 7", the final film from late actor Paul Walker, is expected to break numerous box office records upon its release, including becoming the highest-grossing April opening in U.S. history. The movie, directed by James Wan, features Vin Diesel and Michelle Rodriguez reprising their roles from the previous films in the franchise. With a wide release across 4,003 theaters, it is also the most extensive domestic rollout in Universal's history. The film is poised to surpass the $115 million opening weekend of "Captain America: The Winter Soldier" and potentially become the highest-grossing film of 2015. It marks a significant milestone for the franchise, which has been a huge success thanks to the popularity of the street-racing series starring Walker.

Cesc Fabregas' form has declined significantly after a strong start to the season, with the Spanish midfielder struggling to make an impact in the second half of the Premier League campaign. His recent performances have raised concerns among fans and pundits alike, with some questioning whether he can overcome his slump to help Chelsea achieve success. Despite being one of the top players in the league, Fabregas' statistics suggest that his form may not be sustainable, with only one assist in his last five games. With the pressure mounting on him to deliver, Fabregas' future at Chelsea hangs in the balance.

A horrific medical experiment in Guatemala, where the US tested syphilis on over 700 people, including children, using untested treatments and procedures, has led to a lawsuit against Johns Hopkins University. The victims, mostly orphans and vulnerable populations, including soldiers, prostitutes, and mentally ill individuals, are suing the university for $1 billion, claiming they were intentionally infected with syphilis. The study, which lasted from 1945 to 1956, involved injecting patients with the disease and observing their symptoms, despite knowing the risks. The lawsuit seeks to hold Johns Hopkins accountable for the harm caused to the victims and their families.

Nelly, a 40-year-old hip-hop artist, was arrested in Tennessee on drug charges after a state trooper stopped his private bus on Interstate 40. The bus was found to have marijuana, methamphetamine, and other drug paraphernalia, as well as handguns, during a search. Nelly was charged with felony possession of drugs, simple possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia. He was released on bail and left the jail after posting it.

A Japanese woman gave her cheating boyfriend an unexpected surprise when she soaked his expensive Apple collection in a bathtub, dumping his iMac, iPhone, iPad, and accessories into the water. The unnamed girlfriend had clearly known how to hurt her partner deeply, dumping his prized possessions in the tub after discovering his infidelity. The act of revenge was swift and merciless, causing irreparable damage to the devices. Many people online praised the woman's bold move, calling it "sweet revenge" and "the best way to deal with cheaters." Others commended the woman for showing strength and resilience in the face of betrayal.

Bayern Munich won 1-0 against Borussia Dortmund in their Bundesliga match, with Robert Lewandowski scoring the winning goal. Jurgen Klopp expressed disappointment with the performance, saying Bayern deserved to win despite creating several chances. Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreed, stating that the team created enough chances to win. Lewandowski's goal was seen as a highlight for Bayern, while Dortmund felt they lacked punch and focus throughout the game. The result keeps Bayern 10 points ahead of Dortmund in the standings.

President Barack Obama visited Jamaica on Thursday, becoming the first American president to do so since President Ronald Reagan in 1982. He met with Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller and other Caribbean leaders, solidifying strong ties between the two nations. Obama's visit marked a significant moment in improving relations between the US and Cuba, after decades of estrangement. The US removed Cuba from its list of state sponsors of terrorism, a move seen as a powerful opportunity for cooperation and goodwill.

Pope Francis delivered a powerful message during his "Urbi et Orbi" address, calling for an end to violence and promoting peace in various regions around the world. He specifically addressed conflicts in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Yemen, Nigeria, and South Sudan, urging leaders to put aside their differences and work towards a peaceful resolution. The Pope also expressed hope for peace in Israel-Palestine, Ukraine, and the release of those affected by human rights abuses. In addition, he emphasized the importance of addressing economic exploitation and corruption, particularly against vulnerable populations such as the poor and marginalized. Ultimately, Pope Francis concluded the address with a message of hope and joy, wishing everyone a happy Easter.

In a steamy new campaign for Linda Farrow eyewear, Irina Shayk poses in a series of sultry photoshoots with model Jarrod Scott, showcasing the brand's SS15 collection. The Russian supermodel, who recently ended things with her long-term partner Cristiano Ronaldo, looks incredibly glamorous in various outfits, including plunging metallic swimsuits and retro-inspired sunglasses. The behind-the-scenes footage reveals a playful and flirtatious dynamic between the two, with Jarrod Scott often getting in on the action. The campaign, shot in Los Angeles, features a mix of candid moments and posed shots, highlighting the versatility of the eyewear.

Polish prince Janek Zylinski has challenged Nigel Farage to a sword fight over his criticism of immigration, posting an online video declaring "enough" of the Ukip leader's views. Zylinski, a descendant of a Polish war hero, claims he has had enough of Farage's anti-immigration rhetoric and suggests they can settle their differences through a duel or a verbal sparring match. Zylinski, who fought alongside Polish soldiers in World War II, says a duel with swords is a traditional way for aristocrats to resolve disputes. Farage responded by defending his stance on immigration, saying it's a legitimate concern and that the UK needs to attract skilled workers to boost manufacturing.
people who live here who are scared and anxious about the situation.'

Dani Alves, a key defender for Barcelona, has sparked rumors of a potential move to Manchester United despite being out of contract at the end of the current season. His contract expires on June 30, and while Barcelona's decision to extend his contract is unclear, sources suggest they're offering him a two-year deal with options for a third year based on performance. However, Alves' camp claims the offer is a one-year deal with a second year contingent on playing a certain number of games, which raises questions about whether he'll accept. Meanwhile, Manchester United are reportedly interested in signing him, with a three-year deal on the table, although sources close to the club claim it's a "no-brainer" for them.

A 33-year-old hairdresser, Kate Temple, was jailed for 20 months after admitting to inflicting grievous bodily harm on a woman, Shelley Williams, at a hog roast party in Seaham, County Durham. During an argument, Temple bit off a chunk of Williams' ear while trying to buy another drink from a bar, causing Williams to suffer serious injuries. The incident occurred at a charity event, where Temple had met Williams and her partner, and she had allegedly been having an affair with her partner. Temple claimed she acted in self-defense, but prosecutors argued that she had intentionally attacked Williams. Williams suffered significant injuries, including a permanent disability, and was forced to undergo reconstructive surgery.

Jenson Button believes McLaren is making progress in the new Formula One season, having started strong in Australia but showing signs of improvement in Malaysia despite a severe lack of pace. He hopes to continue improving and eventually catch up with his rivals, particularly the likes of Red Bull and Sauber. Button also appreciates the cooler air in Shanghai, which may help generate better tire temperature, allowing for faster progress. With Honda's new power unit, McLaren has made significant strides, and Button sees potential for further gains. The team is now looking towards the upcoming Chinese Grand Prix, where they aim to push themselves against the likes of the Red Bulls and Sauber.

Claudia Martin, a 33-year-old mother-of-five, was convicted of suffocating her newborn baby daughter by filling her mouth with toilet paper and hiding the body in a suitcase. The baby was born alive, but died shortly after due to severe injuries sustained during the act. Martin claimed she did not intend to harm the child, but was unable to dispose of the body due to the presence of paramedics. A jury acquitted her of murder charges, but convicted her of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility. Martin was sentenced to be held until further proceedings.

AP McCoy's mount, Mr Mole, has been installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre will also compete against him. This marks a rare appearance for McCoy, who announced his retirement from riding earlier this year. Mr Mole will be ridden by AP McCoy in what will be his final ride before hanging up his jockey's helmet. A seven-runner line-up includes other notable entries such as Mick Channon's Somersby.

A woman in Cambridge struggled to stay afloat after tumbling from a punt, but was rescued by her friends and staff after disappearing underwater. The incident occurred during a balmy Easter weekend, with temperatures soaring to nearly 21C in some areas. The woman, who couldn't swim, was pulled to safety by her friends and staff, who used a punt to rescue her. The incident highlights the risks associated with punting, especially for those who aren't strong swimmers.

West Indies' Marlon Samuels has taken a significant step in inspiring his teammates with his disciplined approach to the game, mirroring the example set by former captain Mike Atherton's leadership in the past. Samuels' determination and grit in facing the moving ball in a demanding Test match is reminiscent of the likes of Jonathan Trott, who endured a grueling innings to reach a century. As the West Indies look to build a strong foundation for their future success, Samuels' commitment to applying himself to every aspect of the game will be crucial. His ability to adapt and persevere under pressure will serve as a model for his teammates, particularly in the face of adversity. By taking the difficult road, Samuels will ultimately earn the respect of his peers and contribute to the team's long-term sustainability.

A police officer named Michael Slager is accused of killing Walter Scott while responding to a call about a broken brake light. The incident occurred in North Charleston, South Carolina, and multiple videos contradict the official story, showing Slager firing his Taser on Scott despite being handcuffed. The police department has released personnel records, including Slager's education background, which suggests he worked as a waiter before joining the police force. An investigation by the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division found that Slager fired his Taser without stopping Scott, leading to allegations of misconduct.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, appeared in the video for Ricky Martin's hit song "La Vida Loca" and later denied claims that she tried to take her own life after collapsing in a luxury apartment in Milan. She was hospitalized and treated for low blood pressure, but later released a statement saying she was recovering well and had no intention of ending her life. Moric posted several photographs of her injuries on social media, which sparked controversy when Italian media reported that she had attempted suicide. Despite this, Moric's boyfriend confirmed that she was indeed present at the scene of the incident and had tried to take her own life.

Juventus' 0-0 draw against Monaco in the Champions League semi-finals means they progress 1-0 on aggregate. The Italian side's defensive solidity and "ugly" style of play were praised by Patrice Evra, who believes this is a trait that can serve them well in future tournaments. Evra also commended Monaco for their performance despite losing 0-0, saying they deserved more points. The win marked Juventus' first Champions League semi-final appearance since 2002-03.

A family's peaceful day trip to the zoo turned into a terrifying experience when a 2-year-old girl beat her chest at a silverback gorilla, causing the massive animal to run at the onlookers and throw its full weight against a pane of glass. The incident occurred at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo, where the child's actions seemed to startle the gorilla, leading it to become aggressive. The gorilla then launched itself at the girl, cracking the glass with significant force, forcing the family to flee in terror. The incident highlights the dangers of interacting with wild animals, particularly those considered endangered species like mountain gorillas.

John Suchet, a British actor, tragically lost his wife Bonnie in 2015 due to a decade-long battle with dementia. His relationship with Bonnie was "made in heaven," according to him, and he spoke openly about the impact it had on his life, sharing his experiences through books and public appearances. Fans took to social media to offer their condolences, and Suchet's comments about the sadness of watching Bonnie suffer from dementia resonated deeply. He reflected on the importance of kindness towards those affected by the disease, particularly in terms of treating others with dignity despite their condition.

Ben and Shelby Offrink, a couple from Caledonia, Michigan, met in college and started a study group focused on calculus-based physics. However, their lives took a dramatic turn when Shelby was diagnosed with a rare type of brain cancer called an intramedullary glioblastoma, which lodged in her spine. Despite undergoing surgery and treatment, Shelby's condition worsened, leading to a new diagnosis of multiple tumors in her brain. Now, Ben is facing a new challenge as he navigates a second round of treatments and searches for a cure, while also caring for his wife and two young daughters.

Real Madrid's attack is facing a difficult decision as they face a lineup conundrum with several key players unavailable due to injury. Carlo Ancelotti must decide whether to include Gareth Bale or Luka Modric in his starting XI, given their impressive form. The team's attacking prowess was evident when they hit nine past Granada, but their recent performances suggest they may not be firing on all cylinders. With several key players missing, Ancelotti now faces a tough task of selecting the perfect starting lineup.

Floyd Mayweather will face off against Manny Pacquiao in the highly anticipated "Fight of the Century" at the MGM Grand on May 2. Mayweather has been preparing for the bout by posing for photos with Motown legend Gladys Knight, who met him during a training session. Knight posted a picture with Mayweather on Twitter, thanking him for supporting her at the gym. Mayweather is set to receive a significant payday from the fight, with estimates suggesting he could earn up to £120 million. The two fighters have a long-standing rivalry, with Pacquiao being considered one of Mayweather's rivals.

Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind to help him overcome anxiety and find his "inner voice" while campaigning for office. The firm's services aim to improve politicians' communication skills through neuroscience and business psychology techniques. Despite struggling to convince voters, Miliband has seen a slight boost in popularity since hiring the firm. The firm's methods focus on building leadership skills and helping politicians develop their public speaking abilities.

A married limousine manager, Raymond Townsend, was found liable for sexual harassment and created a hostile work environment after sending explicit texts to his employee, Geralyn Ganci, who reported him to her employer, US Limousine. Ganci claimed that Townsend made unwanted advances, including sending her explicit texts and asking her to meet him in person, and even threatened to harm himself if she didn't comply. The company ultimately fired Ganci, and Townsend was ordered to pay her $1 million in damages and fees. Ganci won a settlement of $1.7 million, which includes $550,000 in compensatory damages and $650,000 in punitive damages.

Thiago made his return to action for Bayern Munich in a 1-0 win over Borussia Dortmund, admitting it was an "emotional" experience. He had missed nearly two years due to a serious knee injury and praised the support of his teammates and fans. Thiago expressed gratitude towards the club, coaches, and team-mates for their encouragement during this time. Despite feeling fatigued, he remains hopeful about returning to full fitness and contributing to the team's pursuit of the treble under manager Pep Guardiola.

David Cameron, the former UK Prime Minister, faced backlash after accusing the BBC of peddling misinformation when questioned about his favorite sport, foxhunting. He claimed he had previously stated that foxhunting was his favorite sport, but later admitted to writing an article for the magazine where he expressed frustration with the Hunting Act. However, he denied saying this publicly, suggesting that the article was written by someone else. A BBC presenter later apologized for the mistake, stating that it was a "cock-up" rather than a conspiracy.

Actress Gwyneth Paltrow has participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, where she spent $29 on a week's worth of groceries using only food stamps. This is part of a larger effort by celebrity chef Mario Batali and musician Sting to raise awareness about the challenges faced by those on food stamps. The challenge aims to show that even with limited resources, people can still access basic necessities like food. The initiative is in response to recent cuts to food stamps, which have led to increased demand at local soup kitchens and food pantries. By participating, Paltrow hopes to educate others about the struggles of living on a limited budget.

Dozens of staff at Manchester United's Megastore, including mascot Fred the Red, are sweating over their futures due to the impending expiration of their contract with Nike, which includes a world-record £750m kit deal. The staff claim they are being kept in the dark about their job security, while Nike claims they are in constant communication with the club. Fred the Red, a beloved fixture at Old Trafford, is among those concerned about their future. The Megastore is located near the East Stand and attracts global visitors, making its closure a significant blow to the club. The staff are likely to face a difficult decision on July 31 when their contract expires.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers 2-1 in the FA Cup sixth-round replay, overcoming a 161-minute stalemate to reach their 24th Cup semi-final. Philippe Coutinho scored the decisive goal in extra time, breaking the deadlock and securing victory. The match saw a series of stoppages due to injuries and missed opportunities, but Liverpool ultimately prevailed. Blackburn Rovers were denied several chances throughout the game, while Coutinho's goal proved decisive. Sportsmail's Oliver Todd praised Coutinho's individual performance, describing him as "mercurial" and "heroic".

A heartwarming video shows six blindfolded children being reunited with their mothers, who are identified solely by touch and scent. The video, titled "The Unique Connection", aims to celebrate the special bond between mothers and children. The children gather in a row, take hands and touch each other, and eventually locate their mothers' faces. The video has gone viral, garnering over 2.8 million views since its release.

Ian Watson, a 38-year-old former Salford player-coach, is poised to return to the field after stepping up his training ahead of a crucial match against Castleford. With several key players out due to suspension or injury, Watson could potentially fill in as a player-coach role. This move comes after his last game for Salford in the Championship was played in June. As one of the oldest players in Super League, Watson would become the oldest player to take the field in the competition. His decision to step back into coaching is seen as a way to stay involved in the sport he loves.

Jordan Spieth took the first-round lead at the Masters with a stunning 64, becoming the youngest first-round leader in Masters history. He shared the lead with Justin Rose and Ernie Els, posting six birdies in seven holes to set himself apart from the pack. Spieth's incredible run included a birdie on the 18th, where he successfully sunk a 25-foot putt to take control of the tournament. Meanwhile, Justin Rose consolled fellow amateur Gunn Yang after his round, praising his performance despite a disappointing start. Spieth's remarkable display marked a welcome change from his usual form, which had seen him struggle to break par in recent weeks.

England captain Alastair Cook must focus on the upcoming Test series against the West Indies, despite being "desperate" to avoid distractions amidst seismic changes in the cricket world. The series is considered one of the most important of his career, and defeat could be "unthinkable". Cook's team faces a three-Test battle, with the pressure mounting after the departure of key players like Paul Downton and Kevin Pietersen. The series begins on Monday, and Cook is determined to keep his team focused and avoid slipping up. With the ECB introducing new leadership and coaching, the stakes are high, and Cook knows he cannot afford to let his guard down.

The US Department of Defense announced plans to exhume the remains of nearly 400 sailors and Marines killed in the sinking of the USS Oklahoma in Pearl Harbor, 75 years after the incident. The decision comes after advances in forensic science and technology have made it possible to identify more remains using DNA and other methods. The Pentagon aims to identify up to 388 servicemen within five years, with the goal of returning their remains to families. The process involves notifying families and providing closure through a burial ceremony, while also ensuring that the remains are handled with dignity and respect. The USS Oklahoma was sunk on December 7, 1941, during the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, resulting in the loss of 429 lives.

A YouTube video featuring an entertainer named Yousef Saleh Erakat, who disguises himself as a homeless person, finds that offering money to passersby does not elicit kindness, but rather anger and hostility. Erakat attempts to flip the script by offering money to those who seem willing to reciprocate, but ultimately receives backlash from both men who refuse to accept his generosity. Despite the negative reactions, Erakat concludes that true wealth lies in humility and kindness, and that even the most impoverished individuals can be considered "rich" in terms of their emotional state. The video ends with Erakat's channel gaining over 5 million subscribers after sharing his provocative experiment.

A 36-year-old man, Wesley Hadsell, was arrested and charged with breaking into a Norfolk home in connection with the disappearance of his 18-year-old stepdaughter, Anjelica Hadsell, who has been missing since March 2. Her grandmother, Katherine Hadsell, expressed frustration with the lack of progress in finding her daughter, stating that police have been "doing nothing" to locate her. The police have searched a pond near Carrsville, Virginia, and have found a white van belonging to the company where Wesley Hadsell works, but have not yet identified anyone taking his daughter. The investigation is ongoing, and the family is seeking answers about how the police were led to the pond.

Researchers have developed a drone called Joggobot that flies alongside joggers to keep them company and track their progress. The drone follows a set path and can detect the jogger's speed and direction, providing a sense of peer pressure and motivation. The technology has been tested on 13 joggers who ran for an average of 26 minutes, with most finding it effective in keeping them motivated. The drone's ability to track speed and direction allows it to adapt to different terrain and weather conditions, making it suitable for various physical activities such as cycling, rowing, and cross-country skiing.

Matthew Bird, a man from Ashburton, New Zealand, quit his well-paid job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic due to a $600-a-month hike in child support payments. The increase resulted in him paying only $38,000 per year, down from $70,000. This decision allowed him to halve his monthly child support payment to $554. Many others, like Bird, are facing similar challenges, including truck driver Dean Sorenson, whose child support payments increased by $172-a-month.

A British man, Navinder Singh Sarao, has been accused of causing the 2010 "flash crash" by manipulating the US stock market through special computer software. The incident occurred on May 6, 2010, when £570 billion was wiped from the value of America's biggest companies in five minutes. Sarao allegedly used automated trading software to place fake orders and cancel them in under one second, triggering the crash. The US authorities initially suspected him of wrongdoing in 2009, but the case took six years to bring forward due to the complexity of the US derivatives markets. An investigation team involving six agencies in the US and Britain wants Sarao put on trial in New York.

Canadian blogger Lisa Webb, author of "Canadian Expat Mom", shares her experience of moving to France with her vegetable-phobic three-year-old daughter. After initially fearing her child would starve due to limited access to vegetables in French schools, Lisa attended her daughter's school for a week to witness firsthand how children eat meals. She was surprised to find that the children ate a variety of foods, including meat and fruits, without hesitation. Lisa credits the French approach to mealtime, which emphasizes presentation and social interaction, for helping her daughter develop a healthier relationship with food.

A survey found that 64% of adults who shop with friends tend to spend more money than they would if they made purchases independently. This is due to factors such as showing off in front of friends and succumbing to peer pressure. Despite knowing they would overspend, many participants still choose to shop with friends. The survey revealed that 85% of participants have a budget when shopping, but often exceed their planned spending limits. The top items on which people overspend include food, clothing, household items, shoes, and entertainment.

Phillip Schofield, a guest on ITV's This Morning, was left speechless after Ellie Grant, 22, blurted out "silver fox" during an interview. The 22-year-old appeared on the show discussing how she developed Tourette's syndrome, a neurological condition causing involuntary noises and movements, and found love with her deaf fiancé Jordan. The incident occurred during a pre-recorded segment, and viewers took to social media to react with amusement. The couple's unusual relationship and Tourette's diagnosis made headlines, with some hailing it as the "greatest Tourette's TV moment of all time."

Adam Gadahn, a US citizen and al Qaeda operative, was killed in a US government counterterrorism operation in January. He was known for his anti-American rhetoric and was one of the organization's most prominent members, despite being a relatively low-ranking figure. Gadahn was involved in various terrorist activities, including planning attacks in the UK, Australia, and the Middle East, and was designated as a terrorist by the US Department of State in 2006. His final video, released in September 2014, called for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

Jenson Button, a 35-year-old Formula One driver, completed the London Marathon in an impressive time of 2 hours, 52 minutes, and 30 seconds. He ran on behalf of Cancer Research and expressed his delight at finishing the event, saying "I'm chuffed to bits". Button jokingly admitted he was disappointed to finish behind former Olympic rower James Cracknell, who finished first. Despite this, Button praised the overall atmosphere and spirit of the runners, describing it as "amazing" and "collectively emotional".
